Ratings.comment: Dr. Fellinger is a phenomenal professor. I had him for 1200 as a TA and his help during recitation and office hours helped tremendously. I had a very rocky start and things only truly turned around when I reached out for help. He cares about his students and does his best to help you understand anything you're having trouble with!
he's helpful and approachable

Dr.Fellinger is a great teacher. He holds many office hours and provides very detailed and thorough notes. If you do not understand a topic he will work with you until you do. Physics is a very hard subject and youll have to put in work but he makes it bearable!

Physics can be hard at times but when you practice it every day it gets easier. This professor worked out many examples on the lecture notes that were very helpful! Sometimes it can be hard to follow through the steps but understanding is the key to success in this class.

This professor does not give you all the essential equations you need to solve problems. He never touched Inertia equation in or out of class. He does not respond to emails. He makes each physics question a complicated poem that you have to unravel to even consider what is happening in the equation. I had to get a tutor for the first time for this.

Lectures were very clear and well organized, if a bit dry at times, but I can roll with that. I never really talked to him personally but he seemed very approachable and people reported that his office hours were helpful.

people are just quick to judge him. yes he is hard, but i think he makes you better at physics. I would not have passed if it wasn't for him. I think he really understands the concepts and he tries to help you understand. he doesn't just give away free answers. but he does make sure you learn.

Requirements for assignments are not very clear, grading is harsh and the material is not very easy to understand. He rarely teaches the content and frequently rambles on unrelated subjects. He rarely answers questions and when he does he is obnoxious about it. Often gets too close to you when talking and is generally unpleasant and can be hostile.

Gets very close to you when he tries to talk to you. Speaks cryptically at times when you try to ask him a question. When he does answer a question, it is always snarky. His attitude was always awful, and he often expressed how he did not want to be there.

Only had him as a TA but he was a pretty good TA. His quizzes were difficult but not anything different than the material they were supposed to be on. Very helpful with leading you in the right direction for labs and group work. Very fair grader on quizzes,groupwork,etc.

This guy might be the worst professor to exist. If you get him its over for you. Your going to want to drop out. Dude has no idea how to teach, he writes on a chalk board with terrible handwriting and has 1 slide of content. He also sounds like squidward. He talks about unrelated nonsense for half the class. He def doesnt know what physics is.

I had Dr. Barrett for both Physics 1250 and 1251 and I have to say he is an awful professor. He speaks very condescendingly in his lectures and is terrible at answering questions. The class was an exact copy of 1250 and wasn't much easier. The exams were very difficult, and it's hard to get out of a bad grade. The labs were a waste of time.

Definitely a difficult class but I thought his lectures were easy to understand and I appreciated all the examples and analogies! The quizzes were not easy but I thought most of the exams were pretty fair.

Dr. Barrett's lectures were good. There are loads of resources to help you succeed in Physics 1251. Dr. Barrett offers office hours multiple days of the week, and will help you anytime you come to his office. Physics 1251 is a tough course, but Dr. Barrett is a good professor and truly wants you to succeed. Take advantage of resources!

One of the worst professors I've ever had. His "writing" on iPad during lectures was barely legible and he kept scribbling over his notes. Tests were near impossible, most people scoring in the mid 60s. Labs and homework were boring and arduous. I actually enjoy physics, but this class made me hate it, as it was taught so poorly. Do not recommend.

He is creepy with girls and will make you feel embarrassed for asking questions. He doesnt thoroughly explain anything and bloats about how good at physics he is half of class. He also hovers very uncomfortably and is rude.

Dr. Barrett's lectures were often unorganized and hard to follow. He seemed very uninterested most of the time. The weekly quizzes and homework were very difficult, and very little proper explanation was ever given. I often found myself lost in lectures. Look to YouTube for help, and use the tutor room often.
If you want to not be taught physics and just have him yell "hmmmkayyy" down your ear, take it with him. Avoid if you can.

He is very unorganized and directs ANY concern you have about the course to the course manager and makes it clear he couldnt care less about your questions. His lectures never really explain concepts unless you continue to ask follow up questions until you get the answer you want. Redo homeworks and find sample problems online to prepare for exam

He's not a good prof, he is super disorganized and unclear. When kids asked questions in class, he responded condescendingly. There were multiple lectures where he spent a long time on a proof and later said "You don't need to know this"l. Hes absolutely useless, avoid him if you can. "Mnayyyy"

I don't recommend prof Barrett. His handwriting is difficult to understand, he frequently draws upon confusing metaphors to explain concepts, and he likes to incorporate math topics beyond the scope of the class. Outside of class, he doesn't reply to emails and is condescending in office hours. At least he has a phd, I guess? Don't take him.

Professor Barrett has got to be the worst teacher I have ever had. His lectures are terrible, as you cant read his handwriting and say mkay at least 50 times a lecture. The physics department itself refuses to help their students and will not provide any study material for the final exam. If you have a choice to not take this class, dont take it.

My beef with Dr. Barrett resides more with the physics department itself. 1250 at Ohio State is a mess. The course is so disorganized and there are almost no resources to help learn the content. Dr. Barrett's lectures were hard to follow because of his messy handwriting and he often skipped content that was still covered on the homework.

I thought I had bad handwriting until I attended my first lecture from Barrett. He might as well be communicating in hieroglyphs because no one can understand his lecture notes. He also doesn't know how to teach students the material in a coherent way, so you are on your own to actually learn the course material.
Get ready to read a third graders writing. It seems like this man writes with his left foot. You may or may not actually learn what will be on the test but you will for sure get sick of his "mkays."
Good luck reading his lecture notes. His hand writing is unreadable, and he loves to scribble over his already sloppy diagrams.
Hard class but be you can tell he cares about the students.

Kural is a funny guy who gives pretty good lectures. He also likes to recommend strategies for students to improve themselves at the end of lectures sometimes, which is nice (one time he recommended "Atomic Habits"). The course is very difficult, though, so prepare to put your nose to the grindstone.

Professor Kural does a good job of creating a friendly environment during lectures. The class content can be very challenging and the homework's will require large amounts of time put in outside of class. This was my most difficult class but Professor Kural made the lectures engaging and interesting. He also seemed to genuinely care.
love his accent, made the class more enjoyable

The class is known to be difficult, and it is. I've enjoyed Dr. Kural's lecturers and he approaches difficult concepts in a way that made sense to me. Legitimately a good lecturer, makes lectures entertaining, and approachable in office hours if you need additional help. I recommend taking him as a lecturer if you can.

Physics 1250 sucks no matter what, but Comert makes it a little bit more bearable. He cares deeply about his students and is funny as can be. Sometimes he can overexplain some things which can make things even more confusing, but I think that was more an issue with my skillset. If you have to choose any professor for 1250, choose him.

Class in general sucks, but Prof. Kural gives great lectures, and is very approachable outside of class. He explains things very well, and is always open to questions. If you are taking this class, beware, it is actually awful. The homework is very hard and grade wise it is very test/quiz heavy. It is so important to go to lectures.

Professor Kural was a good lecturer for the class design. His lectures were always straight from the textbook which was nice and I found them pretty engaging. He even took some time in lectures to give life advice at the end which was a pretty funny but showed that he at least cared about his students. However, the online HW in the class is brutal!

Professor Kural is a funny and likeable person. His lectures involved flipping through pre-made slide shows. I feel like I mostly passed the class because of my background in physics, not exactly because of his lectures. I found the slide shows confusing and jumbled with many unnecessary equations. However, I enjoyed his lectures overall.

I like Professor Kural a lot, he's pretty funny and overall a great lecturer. Lots of demos in class (he even did the famous experiment, putting the pendulum against his head and letting it swing). But be warned, physics classes at OSU are extremely difficult, so be ready to do a lot of homework and attend your TA's office hours.

I literally hated physics before taking this class. Thanks to Prof. Kural, I now find it interesting and applicable to life. Overall, he really wants students to understand the material and succeed. The class was very hard but Prof. Kural was very engaging and knowledgeable and I am happy I had him.

Kural was enthusiastic about the material and made lectures exciting. Lectures mainly focused on conceptual topics, with less math, which made me feel unprepared for the majority of math-based group work and exam questions. But overall, I found the lectures interesting.

Physics 1201 sucks! It was one of the most intensive classes I've taken. But Kural is a fantastic instructor. He did a great job of explaining concepts and making the complex concepts much easier to deal with. I would definitely take him again.

Dr. Kural was a solid prof! His quizzes and exams are harder than his lectures, but the large curves (20-30%) make up for it. You really just need to beat the curve for a good grade. Make sure to go to TA office hours for the HW, do textbook problems, and study his groupwork and past quizzes well. If you put in the work, you'll be fine!

Kural was a good professor, but his tests were so hard. They ended up getting a large curve but I would rather have just gotten a good grade in the first place. He explains the physics fairly well, and if you reread the slides before the quizzes you should be good! He wouldnt be my first choice, but certainly not a bad one

Dr. Kural is a great teacher. He is very knowledgeable about physics and does a good job answering questions. The class is group work heavy and the majority of the assignment are graded on completion. The tests are super hard but there are huge curves.

Both midterm averages are 50%, but then curved to a 77%. Kural makes quiz and test questions extremely hard and youll gain little from studying his lecture slides. He has a complex where he doesnt like to repeat himself and can be very rude if you ask him to repeat anything. Wouldve rather taken calc based physics than have to deal with him.

Dr. Kural is the single worst professor I have ever had. He is terrible at making exams (told students that is GOAL was for the average to be less than 50%) and was not willing to listen to student complaints at all. Openly talked down to students and was downright rude. I would not wish his course or even knowing him on anyone. Terrible professor.

Professor Kural was ok. Make sure you use the lecture slides and you will pass. My biggest concern was the structure of exams and quizzes. Everything was multiple choice so no extra credit for showing work. Miss one question and it will cost you on his short quizzes and exams.

Dr. Kural does not foster a very good classroom environment or communication. If you are someone who often emails their professor with questions, don't even bother with this class. Extremely rude over email and office hours. Study 2+ days in advance for quizzes. Quiz questions are extremely difficult compared to lecture. Just learn from the book.

Extremely difficult to understand, cultural barrier (at times rude or socially inappropriate) and rushed through content. Course was held over zoom, so this mode compounded the existing communication issues.
Terrible lectures. She was very difficult to understand because of her pronunciation and she was unhelpful and uncaring outside of class. I do not recommend this professor at all

This is the most difficult class I have ever taken. The weekly homework was incredibly overly difficult. The exams were way too hard. Dr. Lau's lectures were hard to follow at times, but were overall pretty good. She threw in a lot of jokes. They were almost all recorded, which was nice in case I missed one.

This class is suffering. I don't recommend Lau because she doesn't make PowerPoints and doesn't ever cover conceptual questions, which is the main type of questions on the midterms and final. She does post all of the lecture notes and recordings which is nice. Also not helpful with class concerns and redirects you to Ziegler. Low class averages.

Dr. Lau is a genuinely caring professor.  She gives many examples in class, but unfortunately, those are hard to relate to exam and HW questions for intro-level students.  The class itself is absolutely atrocious, that is of little fault to her, though.  The course itself is designed by a manager who has no respect for students or professors.
Her lecturers were awful. Half the time she would skip through fundamental elements of questions and never explain the content. Although she was a good person, her lectures were really bad.

Professor Lau is a caring person but I felt her lectures fell a little short. Sometimes it was difficult to understand her and I felt like the explanations for everything were okay but not great. If you end up with her she's not a bad professor like many of the intro physics courses but not the best either. I'd rate 3.5 if possible

Funny lecturer and a caring professor. Don't be afraid to ask questions if you don't understand something. She can be difficult to understand at times, but usually asking for clarification helps. There is quite a bit of homework though.

She's not the most organized/clear lecturer and occasionally had to pause in the middle of doing a problem to fix serious errors in her work. That being said, she really listens to the class and actually re-explains stuff if the majority request it. When class went online, she was accommodating and made herself extremely available. Ask questions!
Honestly a pretty good professor in-person. Extremely kind and occasionally throws in a few jokes during lectures. A bit hard to understand at times, but overall pretty fair.

I don't know why there are not many students choosing her. But I would say that she is the best professor I have ever met in my whole physics courses. She has the most fair difficulty exam, and everyone who studies is going to get good grade.

Professor Lau is a genuinely kind woman, but unfortunately her class was a nightmare. Lectures were a waste of my time. I ended up relying on the textbook, Kahn Academy, and my stellar TA to pass this class. Her exams varied widely in difficulty between sections. My section's(Lecture time's) exam grades were 15-25% lower than other lecturers exams.

Dr. Yang was one of the best professors I have had at OSU! The class was hard, but his office hours were very helpful and his lectures were interesting! The quizzes are only 5 questions which is stressful, but he based them off of the online homework, so if you study that you're golden!
Caring, down to earth person. Cares about the success of all of his students. He will go above and beyond to help you in this course. Utilize his office hours!

Great lecturer but only covers basic material and expects you to learn the rest through mastering hw. his weekly quizzes are a lot easier compared to other professors since it's exactly like the hw. Outside resources are honestly more useful for this class.

Nice person but his lectures were long and usually pointless. His lecture slides were nonexistent, and he would just write on the chalkboard without checking in with the class. Very clear he's here for research not to teach.

Dr. Yang was a pretty good professor. He did disappear for about 3 weeks in the middle of the semester, but the exams and quizzes were all very fair. The questions on all tests are very similar to the Mastering homework, so as long as you understand the homework, you will do well.

He was a really nice lecturer and always made time for extra office hours if you needed help. Doesn't offer recordings of lectures, so make sure to go because weekly quizzes ar every lecture-heavy. The class itself is difficult, but he made it understandable with how he simplifies problems. Quizzes were a little tough at time because of timing!
He's a really good lecturer and a nice guy. Knows what he is talking about and truly tries to be available for questions.

Fine lecturer for 1200. Rushed through the material a little bit which forced me to teach myself in a few areas. Definitely wanted to see us succeed. His quizzes were fair and had few surprises. Taught the basic material well but didn't do too much more than that.

Professor Yang is such an amazing professor as well as a kind human! He is always available to help students in office hours and makes sure that they fully understand the concepts. 100% would recommend him to anyone for 1200! :)

Dr. Yang was amazing! He is so down to earth and did an amazing job clearly explaining the material. I have never taken physics before and he did a good job at speaking to an audience that may or may not have background knowledge in physics. He has such a good attitude and is very caring.

I feel like he did not explain topics thoroughly enough, but the amount of material required by the physics department is more than time allows. Dr. Yang truly cares about his students and is very helpful when you ask him questions.

Professor Yang is awesome. His lectures are very clear and has examples that are very similar to exam and quiz questions. He happily answers questions, and always explains concepts well. I took Physics 1200 fully online due to covid, and I feel like my understanding of the material wasn't affected in any way by the situation.

Dr. Yang is the best science professor I have had at OSU. He is very knowledgable, and he does a good job of explaining the material. He has interesting demos that keep your attention. His quizzes can get tricky, and you may feel rushed on quizzes/exams, so move quickly. Overall, a solid professor who cares about student success.

If you take Dr. Yang, go to lecture!!! He is fairly good at explaining difficult concepts and if you try to only use the textbook, you could miss vital details. Dr. Yang is clearly super smart but doesn't flaunt it and takes the class at a good pace. He always answers questions with tons of clarity. However, sometimes the quizzes get pretty tricky.

Dr. Yang begins the course assuming you have zero prior knowledge of physics, so every concept is explained very well and in-detail. He does a lot of examples which are extremely helpful. He always stays after lecture to answer questions, even to hep on homework problems. However he writes all the notes/examples on the board so they're not online!

Dr. Yang is one of the best and most caring physics professors at OSU. He is easy to understand and is willing to answer any questions. Even better, the guy is a total genius, but he's the most down-to-earth person I've ever met, which is hard to come by in OSU's physics department. I would definitely recommend taking Dr. Yang's class.

Dr. Yang is awesome. Super funny and helpful guy, he has great examples and makes physics lectures interesting. One of my favorite lectures at Ohio State. Make sure you take his class if you have to take Physics 1200. Class is hard, but if you do all the work and study hard then you will do fine.

Quizzes were not that bad (open notes) His lectures did not really prepare me for  the exams though. The book is better. If it wasn't for my TA Robert Patton, I would not have passed the class. My advice: get robert as a TA and GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS! I was getting 3/5 on quizzes but then with robert's help I was getting 5's mostly (a couple 4's)

Yang knows his stuff! He is very clear and his demonstrations in class are really cool. His exams are really basic and frankly easy if you study so if you put in the time you definitely will get an A! One of the best professors I have had so far definitely recommend

He explains concepts well, and the demos are pretty entertaining, but I always felt like I never had enough time to complete the exams. I feel like you need to be a good test taker to do well. Quizzes weren't too bad and labs were easy though. Homework assignments were also good for understanding the concepts.

I've been using youtube because the professor goes to fast in my opinion. his lecture slides make no sense so i use dave explains physics on youtube and its been a lifesaver so far. Prepare for hella worksheets and group activities and a lot of homework!

Energetic and patient guy. Seems very passionate about physics and genuine student interest in the subject. Lectures move quick and by themselves are insufficient to teach you the material, so you'll have to use the textbook. There is a good deal of homework, but that honestly incentivizes students to look at physics every day, per Ohio State rec.

He rambles about his ADHD medication every single class (not even kidding) and is really unpleasant, cant read the room and is super edgy for no reason. I will say that he definitely knows what he's talking about and is a decent instructor, but I can't stand his personality.
Horrible experience made my friend cry.

While somewhat hindered by an awful department, Dr. Felker tries to make it better for his students, which is very appreciated. However, he has a tendency to come off as condescending sometimes and it can be discouraging. Overall, I think he'd improve with more experience in the classroom, but he's really not awful compared to some other options.
This dude is the hardest grader. I try to get help and never get any help from this dude. He grades so hard and comments the same thing but won't ever help me.

This professor needs to retire. He often soliloquized and ignored students when they raised their hands with questions. What he taught and what he expected his students to know were highly incompatible. I felt helpless knowing I had to learn the concepts on my own. This class is a pain.

Dr.Bolland is a nice guy, but his lectures are horrible. They are all over the place and make no sense and often he falls behind schedule. The quizzes were hard and the exams were even harder. I had to drop and get a W to preserve my GPA and I know a lot of people who did that as well. Avoid at all costs, there are much better physics profs at OSU.

Dr. Bolland needs to retire. He regularly loses his entire train of thought, and mumbles into the board instead of talking to the class. He makes his own quizzes and decides that his section doesn't need formulas. He doesn't answer lecture questions clearly, possibly because he can't hear what you're saying. This whole course is a nightmare.

The has been the worst faculty experience of my life. Professor Bolland does not know how to use technology and no one can hear him during lectures; aside from that he does not teach anything related to the homework or quizzes we receive. Overall this was a terrible experience PLEASE DO NOT TAKE 1250 WITH BOLLAND!!.

Dr. Bolland is a very kind man but his lectures are not great. He quickly switches from one topic to another and sometimes spent over half the lecture deriving equations, even when this wasn't something needed for the class. His quizzes weren't as hard as some other lecturers but definitely were not easy.

He is a very nice man but has some serious flaws for an introductory course lecturer. He skips a lot of important material, which makes the homework extremely difficult to impossible without looking up a tutorial on how to do the problem. Avoid this lecturer as unless you have extensive background knowledge, this class will be extremely difficult!

This would be a fine choice if you took an excellent high school physics class. Otherwise, steer clear of this class. Lectures were pretty useless, go to Lu's section instead or take 1250. They expected the avg grade on the final to be 40% or lower class-wide. This section brought it down. The curve is extreme, and the syllabus is VERY outdated.
I love Dr. Bolland, but please, if you are not a physics major, don't take this class. it is hard.

Read the textbook because going to lecture will be a waste of your time. He is a very funny guy, however his teaching style is very fast paced and covers a lot of things that are not necessary for doing well on the exams.

Bolland loves physics, but falters at teaching it. He often forgets that he is teaching to students with little physics background and neglects to define important variables/topics assuming that students already know the material. As someone who had a strong physics background and was successful in the class, his lectures were tough to sit through.

While they've improved it seems over the years at lecturing, they've still got a while to go. He assumes you know EXACTLY how to do everything before lectures and can master it within a week. Tests are very difficult if you had any difficulty on the homework. Take Physics 1250, it'll save you a headache, plus you'll learn much more smoothly.

Bolland is a very hard lecturer. He assumes you know what is going on. In order to succeed in the class, a lot of studying and extra work is required to understand topics. This is a very very difficult course. If you have any control over it, do not take this class with Bolland as your professor.
A genuinely nice guy who clearly cares about his class, but does not always convey content clearly. Recitations help a lot in learning the content
Dr. Bolland is extremely knowledgeable, however his grading system, and test design philosophy is... unique

I really want to love Dr. Bolland as he is the classic old wacky physics professor, but he's just not a good Professor anymore. Very nice man, and he loves the subject matter but that leads to him getting too excited and forgetting exactly what the lecture is supposed to cover. Exams are crazy difficult unless you study really hard.
Brilliant man, but only followed what he was trying to say based on taking AP last year. Doesn't answer questions very well, but is open to office hours even if they're not 100% helpful.

I believe he is a very smart man but he doesn't really know how to teach people who don't understand the material.  Class is difficult but doable, lots of points from homework and lab to help cushion your grade.  Labs are pointless but easy points so go to them.
Keeps you interested during lectures. Exams are difficult but manageable (Physics 1260)

I took 1250 with Dr Kilcup and enjoyed his lectures, he seems like a fun person and when you talk to him, he is always eager to help. I think he is far too smart to be teaching introductory physics so concepts that should be fairly straight forward tend to get complicated more than they need to be. If you don't have a good grasp on calc good luck.

He's a horrible lecturer. Explains the easiest concepts in the most convoluted way. Wastes a third of the class time by getting sidetracked on stuff. If you take him, be prepared to put all your time into self learning.

Dr. Kilcup is an incredibly smart man however he does not convey this into his lectures. He talks about inconclusive items that have no correlation to the concept being taught and is overall a waste of time. Lectures feel like they are dragging. While he is a great guy I would not recommend taking a course taught by him as you will feel lost.
He does not care for the students that he teaches and does not explain concepts well at all.

He is so slow when he is teaching and he does not know how to convey and explain any concepts. Please if you can, do not take this teacher, he keeps bragging about how he's friends with Bill Gates and not caring about teaching us physics. You have to teach yourself everything.

He is very bad at teaching, he never does practice problems and just reads off slides The top hats he does is just for participation and he does so much he ends up forgetting the point of the lecture that day You will have and must teach yourself everything

Does not teach well at all, only reads off lecture slides. This is a tough course with lots of math around it, so its surprising that he does not ever work out any questions within the units. Does loads of TopHats with each lecture, and does not even explain how to do the questions and just moves on. You will have and must teach yourself everything

Really smart guy but I couldn't learn anything from him after the second week. Be prepared for online HW to take 3-6 hrs a week and extra work given. Midterms multiple choice are worth a lot of points. Be ready to teach yourself everything unless you took some AP physics in high school. Takes attendance with Tophat questions unrelated to tests orHW

I kinda like him. He's a very chill and humorous guy. He replies to emails frequently and usually within 12 hours during weekdays. The whole class was not very difficult, the examples he gave in the class were enough to do well on the exams.
Does not give any examples with helpful instruction. Top hat runs the class and he is unable to explain any questions clearly. Switch out while you still can.

Extremely boring and melatonin inducing professor. He is addicted to top hat questions which he takes for your attendance and he doesn't do too many practice problems during his lectures. Instead, the time that he could be doing practice problems is filled with the time used by useless top hat questions.

I'm currently in his Physics 1250 class. It's hard for me to critique him a lot because he seems like a genuine and nice guy. But, I have heard from others, and learned from personal experience, that his lectures are pretty useless. He dumps a bunch of stuff from the textbook in lecture slides but doesn't actually fully teach the material.

Professor Kilcup is indeed very intelligent. However, when it comes to teaching, he is not the best. It is best to read the textbook than to go to his lectures, and the tests are graded very hard. I believe 1 multiple choice question on the midterm was worth 20 percent of the test. Try to avoid this professor of you can.
He is a very nice person, but I don't think he's the best at teaching. I had to teach myself everything in this class. Also, Dr. Skinner's slides were useful.

I like how he explained physics in a mathematical way. He is also nice person, always show up in his office hour Although his lecture can sometimes be tedious, typically a video and concept explanation and some top hat questions. I will try to read the text books before class and come to his office hour to get a good understanding.

He does not teach well. He expects you to know the concepts before hand, and then during lecture he doesn't solve problems all the way through, often times skipping important steps. He drones on in lecture and he never adjusts his mic so people can hear properly. I would recommend to do homework in lecture and then study on your own.

Lectures were pretty boring and not very useful. He knows what he's talking about but doesn't do a good job of actually teaching it. Weekly quizzes can be pretty difficult at times but the midterms and final were pretty reasonable and you can easily score well as long as you dedicate a decent amount of time to studying and doing practice problems.
Unique in his ability to make his lectures provide the body with extreme amounts of melatonin.

While Dr. Kilcup is indeed a nice person, and knows a lot about the concepts in his class, from my experience, he was not the best at teaching them. It was better to skip his lectures and just read the provided textbook. Exams were hard and required a very deep understanding of concepts that he just touched briefly in class.

Lectures were pretty useless, I only read the textbook and later read Dr. Skinner's notes. He makes the quizzes, and the averages are appalling. Exams aren't bad. Homework can be lengthy and they will help you in any way they can. If you are in his section, I encourage skipping the lecture and reading Dr. Skinner's notes instead.

I would not recommend this TA at ALL. Very rude, mean and doesn't care about students. If you ask for help she will read the problem to you again and leave you more confused, and will interrogate you for needing help. She is not respectful towards the ways different students learn, everything has to be done her way. Seriously would not recommend.

Professor G is a nice lady. She is always willing to answer students' questions if needed. Although this is a GE course, it still has a lot of assignments to do (Question of the day, unit check, and video homework), and has 3 exam and 2 quizzes in total. However, it is really confusing about the Plan-Do-Conclusion format in her assignments.

Decent at explaining physics concepts but struggles with explaining problem solving, even though exams and quizzes constantly require problem solving. Her quizzes were generally fair. Accessible outside of class and makes her office hours clear to students. In general, she also cares about students and wants to see them succeed in the course.

Dr. G is a wonderful professor, don't let these reviews fool you! She is good at explaining concepts and her quizzes are similar to the topics covered in lectures. She made sure to have both in-person and Zoom lecture options for students. The midterms and final is difficult but expected for a class like this.

I'm not sure why all of these horrible ratings are on here. Prof G explains things in a clear, easy-to-grasp way, and is always trying to meet the needs of her students. Physics 2 is a weed out course, and it takes individual work outside of lectures to apply and understand these concepts.

Lectures are useless since she copies from summary notes she posts online. She doesn't do math problems in class, it is just conceptual. Recitations and labs are a mess. Nothing new from physics department. Quizzes extremely difficult, test are slightly easier. Awful professor.

Literally the worst prof ever. Going to class doesnt help. She has a copy of notes page that she just writes over again on the chalk board verbatim and no explanation of why. You can just look at the definitions and equations on the slide yourself and learn the same thing as you would in class. Answers questions vaguely and often wrong

Physics 1200 By far worst/least caring professor I've ever had. Awful lecturer who doesn't make practice problems/exams or post her slides online. Makes her own diagrams for lecture that she basically expects you to memorize since they will show up on quizzes. She gave laughably little effort and had a sub or cancelled lecture 5 times.

Awful lecturer. Goes to fast to write everything down and refuses to post her PowerPoints. Really doesn't care how students do. Will not post reviews or answer keys.  This class should not have been this hard. Consistently ends lecture early then claims we don't have enough time to finish things. Avoid her at all costs.

Terrible at explaining concepts. She explains it super half-baked and seems like she knows she's doing a terrible job at it and still moves on. Make sure you understand homework and quiz problems. Also beware, class gets a bit harder after the first midterm. Avoid.

Lectures are not helpful at all for homework, tests, or quizzes. you will see the tests and have no idea what half of the things on it are because she never went over it in lecture.  She is very unclear and unhelpful. Didn't help that she was also my TA so I got no extra help there. If you can avoid it don't take physics with this professor.

Very unclear about topics in lecture and then gets mad when students do not understand. Either does no problems, or extremely easy problems in class (relative to the homework,quizzes,etc...). If you go to her office hours with questions about the assigned homework, she will just restate the exact wording of the homework question. Avoid this prof.
Very boring lecturer. I'd suggest studying from the book and doing book problems for exams.
Lectures were pointless and a lot of self teaching is needed. Do your best to understand the material on quizzes and practice tests rather than information from lecture.
Tests are ridiculous hard. Not useful to attend lectures. Don't take this class with this professor.

The lectures are definitely a waste of time. Her explanations of concepts are unclear and uses no example problems in lecture. She puts her notes online but they are unorganized and lack detail. The exam and homework problems were tough and wording on exams was VERY unclear.

The lectures were not helpful at all. I get that she wants students to think for themselves to solve complicated problems, but the exams are stupid hard compared to the homework, in-class quizzes and the infrequent examples offered in lecture. She spends most of the lectures deriving formulas using calculus and doing simple examples symbolically.

Sure, the lectures don't spoon feed you the answers to your tests and quizzes but I found lectures to be interesting.  Her style of teaching by writing the notes in class rather than prewriting the slides kept the class well paced and her examples and demos made it easy to pay attention. The tests are hard but manageable with hard work.

Her lectures are a complete waste of time and she only shows conceptual things. Then on the homework and quizzes you have no idea how to implement formulas because she doesn't do any examples in class. Avoid this professor.

I created an account to review this professor. Worst professor I've ever had at Ohio State. This class was ridiculously hard due to the manner of teaching. It's not learning based whatsoever. It's interesting how the test questions aren't that difficult yet the averages are in the 50s, which basically demonstrates that no one learned anything...

Chini is very nice and sweet, but not a great lecturer. She doesn't really explain topics, she just shows her work on the whiteboard. If you took AP physics 1 in HS, you should be good for the first half of the semester. Otherwise, I would use any help from your TA you can get.

Her class atmosphere was good, but the preparation was not sufficient. Sometimes she would make mistakes on the questions, which resulted in unclear knowledge.The slides in class went by quickly, and sometimes I couldn't understand the knowledge points well. However, this was her first year at OSU, so I could understand.

She is very sweet but unfortunately I did not learn much from her. It always seemed like she was unprepared, would run out of time, didn't know how to do the problems, and would frequently make mistakes. She also did not curve our class at all! I have some sympathy as it was her first year teaching at OSU but this class was a trainwreck.
Lectures often missed important concepts, she seemed somewhat unprepared. Tests are graded weird, few questions worth a lot of points. Took extra credit away, even from the students who did it.

Lectures were hard to follow. She posted lecture slides but they were unfinished. Went to her office hours but sometimes it seemed she was even confused on the material, which is unsettling for a student who also doesn't know what they are doing. She ended up taking away the extra credit at the end of the semester bc not enough students did it.

Proffessor Hughes is one of the best professors I have ever had. Yes this class is very tough but she explained things amazingly, truly cares about her students, and is great at physics. This class is confusing so go to lectures and take notes, study for exams. Her office hours are great and she is great at teaching as well as physics.

She cares a lot about student success and her lectures are actually helpful. Lecture slides aren't great so going to class is important. Never went to office hours but did email her and receive quick responses. The subject is very difficult and she does her best to teach it. Exams slightly harder than her practice problems but still very close.
She was okay, a lot of her lecture slides are useless. She does top hat questions in class that help a bit. There was no final curve for her class, which is quite astounding for physics.

This is one of the hardest classes I have had to take, but I am glad I got Prof. Hughes. You can tell she really cares about the students. She is very accessible outside of class. The only thing is that everyone was under the impression the class would be curved by a lot, but ended up being curved by very little.

Class itself is pretty bad but she is a good lecturer. Covered the material well and went at a decent pace. Her office hours are extremely helpful for everything in the class. All the midterms were curved 15-20% but the final and the final grade were not curved at all. She is great and helped a lot but the class is still pretty bad

Tough class, but she teaches well. Slides are always available if you missed a lecture, but a few top hat questions each lecture are taken for attendance. Does a good amount of in class examples and is passionate about the topic
VERY great lecturer, very nice & understanding outside of lecture / office hours, probably the biggest reason I passed this class. Grades are harsh, but at least it's curved.
Very tough course but he does a good job teaching and curves the hell out of it.

One of my favorite professors, the lectures are great, and the assignments are a bit difficult, but I can do them seriously without any problem. The exam difficulty is relatively high but the proportion is relatively limited. Process evaluation is highly valued!
Mr. Schumacher is a funny guy, I like to take his course!

1260 was definitely a very fast paced and difficult class however, if you put in the time and also go to office hours you can do okay. He was very understanding and helpful at office hours and wanted his students to succeed, just the course material is very hard so its not like he can give everyone A's.

This class made me rethink everything. I'm sorry but I cant with the fact that he was so oblivious to peoples struggles with the class. The recitation problems were difficult so I found myself sitting there and waiting for class to end. My peers were really condescending and the set up of the class is not good. Take 1250, its just better!!!!!!!!!!!

Class is extremely fast paced and overwhelming (for me at least). Douglass pays too much attention to those who are doing well and doesn't look after those who aren't; I took a lot of time to understand the material and yet ended with a B-, after a curve that he said he wouldn't be able to do bc people were doing too good. Like gurl BFFR, i cant :(

Do not take this class if you do not have extensive physics experience/really enjoy physics. Spent hours studying for all of the tests and 25+ hours studying for the final and did not receive grades that reflected the time I spent practicing. Only helpful at office hours if you understand the material well enough to ask questions he wants to answer

Excellent professor. He taught the course very clearly, and the portion of daily points is around 65%! Therefore, if you put in the effort, you could get a B+ or above. Moreover, he will give the curve, which is decided by the overall grade distribution (but not stricter than the OSU standard).

Do not take this class if you have not taken AP physics. Grades are determined based on how everyone else does, and it is hard to compete with kids that know it already. Schumacher is overall a decent person, but he did promise us a curve the entire semester and BARELY gave us one at the end. If you have not taken physics before, expect a C.

Though the class is tough, Dr Schumacher is a great lecturer and makes the class super interesting. I had taken a physics course in high school, so the pacing of the class felt good, but I'd assume if this is your first time taking physics then it would be a bit fast. Labs are interesting and never once took up more than half of the allotted time.

Extremely tough course, but if you do all the homework and exam preparations then you should make it out with at least a B+. He curves the course at the end to give about half the students A's, and two-thirds B's. Labs & recitations are free points for showing up. Study hard for exams since they are the driving force of your grade.
A great prof to have for a quite rigorous class. The material is hard, but Shumacher does care about students and is very accessible for questions. Ask him about his laser.

Dr. Schumacher is a phenomenal teacher. He truly cares and he is willing to help with anything, not to mention he is probably the most intelligent teacher I have ever has. The class is insanely difficult, but it is curved pretty hard and if you put in the work (which is a ton), then you can come out with a B+ (ish).

Schumacher is really an excellent professor for FEH. His lectures are informative and engaging. I highly recommend this class if you are interested in E&M. It's not easy, but if you put in the effort you will learn a lot.

Dr. Schumacher is the best professor I've ever had. I had him for both 1260 and 1261, and his lectures were great. He looks at pre-lecture comments and addresses them in class and takes the time to go over homework questions if they were particularly difficult. His classes were a lot of work but the curves are generous.

One of the best in the department. Very diligent about looking at prelecture comments and trying to tailor each lecture around those while still incorporating new material. Funny, but productive lectures. Places a large focus on going to office hours. Office hours are very helpful. Exams were tough but fair.
His office hours are essential

Dr. Schumacher is one of the best teachers/professors I've ever had. He explains physics concepts in such an understanding way and if people are confused he'll go over it again until he believes the class understands. His office hours are almost better than his lectures and he is more than willing to help out when you need it.

Dr. Schumacher is one of the best teachers/professors I've ever had. He is very interactive with the class.  If he senses that people are confused over something, he will find a new unique way to describe it. He is very accessible outside of class and has tons of office hours. Very witty, smart, and down to earth.
This class is VERY easy to fall behind in!! Go to all the lectures. He is funny and makes lessons relatable and make sense in the real world. A good teacher in general.
Passionate professor, hard class. Syllabus says attendance not mandatory, but this professor holds TopHat assignments that make attendance mandatory.

Pierre was a great professor this semester. I enjoyed his lectures, as they were generally helpful, with example problems being done in class, as well as examples of real world applications and demos. Attendance is taken via Tophat questions during lecture, and the questions are a good gauge of if you are understanding the lecture.

Probably one of the worst professors I have had here. Makes many mistakes during lecture, to which she would ask the students what went wrong or what she was missing. Not helpful during office hours, and said she didn't care about your grades and that she's not a good teacher. Emphasis on not a good teacher.

Lectures are terrible, all show work is done on a blackboard with consistent errors and skips a multitude of steps aswell as talks into the board to where you can't hear what she is saying. She means well but dosent translate. Also prep material is minimal and is usually too late to be useful

The worst 1250 professor, respectfully. I've never taken physics before & stopped going to lecture b/c it was so unhelpful & got a tutor instead. Take another prof tho &  heed my warnings.
it's clear that she would rather be doing her research than teaching. lectures are overall disorganized, unengaging, and unhelpful.

Outside of lectures OSU profs have no control over the homework, the webassigns are hell but they are doable.

She doesn't want to be here and you could tell. Often confused at her own notes. There were multiple instances she did a demonstration in class and stated "yeah I don't know why this happened but department want me to do this." Doesn't know anything about the class.

You can tell that she'd rather be working on her research than teaching. She seems like a nice lady but lectures aren't very structured, the slides contain basically no information and she instead writes everything out which is confusing and very unengaging.

I could tell from the jump that Prof Connolly did not want to be teaching classical mechanics. She does not wants to be there and doesn't know what's going on. Failed to answer many questions. Dr. Connolly is very knowledgable, but does not give very coherent or planned out lectures. She pauses a lot, and is very hard to understand if you have not taken physics before. I had her for Physics 1250, combined with TA Daniel Brandenburg (absolutely atrocious TA, doubt he really knows physics, dodges questions regularly) Connolly has good lecturs, and they really are indepth but she makes many mistakes, stutters a lot, and usually is corrected by students. A kind person, but makes multiple errors during her lectures. Also stutters a lot and says "uh" and "um" at least 5 times each sentence. Prepare to self-study a lot and make sure to attend office hours to truly understand material.

Dr. Connolly is an incredible professor and inspired me to stay a physics major. She is a really great professor and really cares about her students and about physics. Brilliant and extremely helpful. She is very patient and helps you work through a problem yourself to make sure you understand.

Best Physics teacher at osu to date. If she was teaching this semester I would take her again. Honest and fair. Willing to help. First midterm average, second midterm easy but the final was awful. Her quizzes followed the same pattern. Some easy some average and some you needed to be Albert Einstein to figure out. Keeps you on your toes. STUDY!!!!!

Dr. Connolly did a great job for her first time teaching this class.  While sometimes she got confused or made mistakes in her lectures, she always corrected them.  Her office hours were very helpful to clear up confusion too.  She was clear in what she expected you to know for the exams, giving lists of problems and topics to understand.

She was a decent enough professor.  I found her lectures to be confusing sometimes, and she would make a lot of errors.  It is clear that she knows the information though.  Some of her quizzes are impossible, while others are easy.  Her first midterm was tough, second was easy, and the final was brutal.  She is a very fair professor though.

Unclear at times, makes assumptions that you know the math behind the content. Often makes mistakes that have to be caught. Responsive emailer. Often gives hints as to what is on exams. If you put in the work and do well on the quizzes overall, you will do well in the class.

For the love of all that is holy, if you are taking physics 1201, and you find out you're with this guy, IMMEDIATELY drop the course and find another section or take it another semester. He is by far the worst lecturer I have ever here at OSU. He is condescending, makes unrelated unfunny dry jokes, and gets confused probably 2-3 times PER LECTURE.
Every question feels like a trick. Doesn't help and clearly tries to show he is smarter than everyone else. Avoid him at all costs

He rambles about his ADHD medication every single class (not even kidding) and is really unpleasant, cant read the room and is super edgy for no reason. I will say that he definitely knows what he's talking about and is a decent instructor, but I can't stand his personality.
Horrible experience made my friend cry.

While somewhat hindered by an awful department, Dr. Felker tries to make it better for his students, which is very appreciated. However, he has a tendency to come off as condescending sometimes and it can be discouraging. Overall, I think he'd improve with more experience in the classroom, but he's really not awful compared to some other options.

Dr. Winer has a hard job of teaching calc-based physics course to a group of around 70 people at a time, but he does a pretty good job. He always posts his slides/notes and they're super helpful for the quiz and test preparation. Definitely look at the quiz/exam objectives to pass those. He's also very helpful during his office hours.

Amazing professor! A professor who pays attention to daily tasks, with 66% of the scores coming from regular grades, and places great emphasis on the learning process! The exam is a bit challenging, but it can still be solved.
I like Mr. Winer. I learn a lot about electricity and magnetism from his course. Although the exams are challenging, getting a good grade is possible with enough effort.
Genuine, kind, caring professor. Course content is very difficult but going to office hours and doing extra practice helps. I wish he could teach all of my physics courses :)

Just a very genuine person who truly cares about what he teaches. He makes sure to help students understand and is very patient. One of the best professors at OSU no doubt. Course content is very difficult though.

Dr. Winer is a very good professor. He takes good care of his students. His lecture was so clear that I, as a person with no foundation in electromagnetism, could understand it. Physics 1271 may not be an easy A to get, but Brian Winer is highly recommended!

Professor Winer is the best physics professor you could ask for. Caring, helpful, and a clear grader, he offers multiple opportunities for office hours throughout every week. He offers many opportunities to get easy points so that quizzes and exams don't tank your grade. You're allowed to create your own equations sheets for exams as well.
Dr. Winer is the greatest Professor I have ever had and truly cares for all of his students. Dr. Winer is my definition of an absolute Chad

Professor Winer is an incredible lecturer who truly cares about the material he teaches. He makes everything engaging and never makes the students feel bad about not knowing something. He is hilarious and one of the best professors I've ever had. I would like to note I took 1270 instead of 1250H, but the class option was not available.

Best physical sciences professor I've ever had. He does an amazing job of breaking down complicated subjects into really simple and intuitive concepts. All the material on tests and quizzes comes directly from topics discussed in class and is focused on understanding the ideas rather than just doing a bunch of complicated algebra and calculus.
My favorite professor I had first semester. He made sure grades were fair, he always explained himself when asked, and office hours were extremely helpful. I had 0 issues with him.
Not the easiest, but always fair. There' no recitation, but he's very helpful if you go to his office hours.
I love this professor and he brings me lots of fine time in physics. I really enjoy his class.

hes an amazing and passionate professor?I never thought I would enjoy doing physics but his passion and clarity in his class changes everything and I learned a lot from him,he's like the perfect physics professor for me!He also has an interesting personality and his class is never boring!

really good teacher, fair quizzes and tests, if you pay attention he'll practically give you the answers to the tests.  if you do the homework and study a little you will do well in his class.  makes the info interesting.  highly recommended
Great teacher. Willing to give hints if you go to office hours. Pulls quiz questions right from the textbook and the Tuesday worksheets. Study and you'll do well.

I am really impressed with the physics department at Ohio State. The textbook for this course is great, and Professor Winer is an animated and very clear instructor. Tests and Quizzes are fair. Homework and Lab are easy points, so get all of them. I enjoyed this class.
A great Instructor. Never so an instructor that is willing to help as he does. His exams are very fair; if you study you'll do well. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

Prof. Winer was a fantastic teacher.  He explains the material thoroughly. He's always available and has organized, clear notes available online. The class is somewhat hard, but it's physics, so that's expected. I recommend Prof. Winer very highly!
extremely helpful, i would recommend his class to anyone.  Always available and very fair in grading.   Notes were easy to understand and answers were available on his website.  Best prof to have.

Awesome. Best physics teacher I've had. Very helpful with regards to explaining material more thoroughly, giving help on homework (unlike a lot of teachers). Very clear lectures since he prepares his own notes which he follows through class. Very structured and easy to follow.
Prof Winer knows what he is doing and is enthusiastic about the subject, but he lectures to the room - not to the students in it.  If you aproach him personally he is willing to give guiding hints.
Great physics teacher.  His lectures always cleared things up and his office hours were extremely helpful.  Take his class if you can.

Her quizzes followed the same pattern. Some easy some average and some you needed to be Albert Einstein to figure out. Keeps you on your toes. STUDY!!!!!

Dr. Connolly did a great job for her first time teaching this class.  While sometimes she got confused or made mistakes in her lectures, she always corrected them.  Her office hours were very helpful to clear up confusion too.  She was clear in what she expected you to know for the exams, giving lists of problems and topics to understand.

She was a decent enough professor.  I found her lectures to be confusing sometimes, and she would make a lot of errors.  It is clear that she knows the information though.  Some of her quizzes are impossible, while others are easy.  Her first midterm was tough, second was easy, and the final was brutal.  She is a very fair professor though.

Unclear at times, makes assumptions that you know the math behind the content. Often makes mistakes that have to be caught. Responsive emailer. Often gives hints as to what is on exams. If you put in the work and do well on the quizzes overall, you will do well in the class.

Dr. Fellinger is a phenomenal professor. I had him for 1200 as a TA and his help during recitation and office hours helped tremendously. I had a very rocky start and things only truly turned around when I reached out for help. He cares about his students and does his best to help you understand anything you're having trouble with!
he's helpful and approachable

Dr.Fellinger is a great teacher. He holds many office hours and provides very detailed and thorough notes. If you do not understand a topic he will work with you until you do. Physics is a very hard subject and youll have to put in work but he makes it bearable!

Physics can be hard at times but when you practice it every day it gets easier. This professor worked out many examples on the lecture notes that were very helpful! Sometimes it can be hard to follow through the steps but understanding is the key to success in this class.

This professor does not give you all the essential equations you need to solve problems. He never touched Inertia equation in or out of class. He does not respond to emails. He makes each physics question a complicated poem that you have to unravel to even consider what is happening in the equation. I had to get a tutor for the first time for this.

Lectures were very clear and well organized, if a bit dry at times, but I can roll with that. I never really talked to him personally but he seemed very approachable and people reported that his office hours were helpful.

people are just quick to judge him. yes he is hard, but i think he makes you better at physics. I would not have passed if it wasn't for him. I think he really understands the concepts and he tries to help you understand. he doesn't just give away free answers. but he does make sure you learn.

Requirements for assignments are not very clear, grading is harsh and the material is not very easy to understand. He rarely teaches the content and frequently rambles on unrelated subjects. He rarely answers questions and when he does he is obnoxious about it. Often gets too close to you when talking and is generally unpleasant and can be hostile.

Gets very close to you when he tries to talk to you. Speaks cryptically at times when you try to ask him a question. When he does answer a question, it is always snarky. His attitude was always awful, and he often expressed how he did not want to be there.

Only had him as a TA but he was a pretty good TA. His quizzes were difficult but not anything different than the material they were supposed to be on. Very helpful with leading you in the right direction for labs and group work. Very fair grader on quizzes,groupwork,etc.

This guy might be the worst professor to exist. If you get him its over for you. Your going to want to drop out. Dude has no idea how to teach, he writes on a chalk board with terrible handwriting and has 1 slide of content. He also sounds like squidward. He talks about unrelated nonsense for half the class. He def doesnt know what physics is.

I had Dr. Barrett for both Physics 1250 and 1251 and I have to say he is an awful professor. He speaks very condescendingly in his lectures and is terrible at answering questions. The class was an exact copy of 1250 and wasn't much easier. The exams were very difficult, and it's hard to get out of a bad grade. The labs were a waste of time.

Definitely a difficult class but I thought his lectures were easy to understand and I appreciated all the examples and analogies! The quizzes were not easy but I thought most of the exams were pretty fair.

Dr. Barrett's lectures were good. There are loads of resources to help you succeed in Physics 1251. Dr. Barrett offers office hours multiple days of the week, and will help you anytime you come to his office. Physics 1251 is a tough course, but Dr. Barrett is a good professor and truly wants you to succeed. Take advantage of resources!

One of the worst professors I've ever had. His "writing" on iPad during lectures was barely legible and he kept scribbling over his notes. Tests were near impossible, most people scoring in the mid 60s. Labs and homework were boring and arduous. I actually enjoy physics, but this class made me hate it, as it was taught so poorly. Do not recommend.

He is creepy with girls and will make you feel embarrassed for asking questions. He doesnt thoroughly explain anything and bloats about how good at physics he is half of class. He also hovers very uncomfortably and is rude.

Dr. Barrett's lectures were often unorganized and hard to follow. He seemed very uninterested most of the time. The weekly quizzes and homework were very difficult, and very little proper explanation was ever given. I often found myself lost in lectures. Look to YouTube for help, and use the tutor room often.
If you want to not be taught physics and just have him yell "hmmmkayyy" down your ear, take it with him. Avoid if you can.

He is very unorganized and directs ANY concern you have about the course to the course manager and makes it clear he couldnt care less about your questions. His lectures never really explain concepts unless you continue to ask follow up questions until you get the answer you want. Redo homeworks and find sample problems online to prepare for exam

He's not a good prof, he is super disorganized and unclear. When kids asked questions in class, he responded condescendingly. There were multiple lectures where he spent a long time on a proof and later said "You don't need to know this"l. Hes absolutely useless, avoid him if you can. "Mnayyyy"

I don't recommend prof Barrett. His handwriting is difficult to understand, he frequently draws upon confusing metaphors to explain concepts, and he likes to incorporate math topics beyond the scope of the class. Outside of class, he doesn't reply to emails and is condescending in office hours. At least he has a phd, I guess? Don't take him.

Professor Barrett has got to be the worst teacher I have ever had. His lectures are terrible, as you cant read his handwriting and say mkay at least 50 times a lecture. The physics department itself refuses to help their students and will not provide any study material for the final exam. If you have a choice to not take this class, dont take it.

My beef with Dr. Barrett resides more with the physics department itself. 1250 at Ohio State is a mess. The course is so disorganized and there are almost no resources to help learn the content. Dr. Barrett's lectures were hard to follow because of his messy handwriting and he often skipped content that was still covered on the homework.

I thought I had bad handwriting until I attended my first lecture from Barrett. He might as well be communicating in hieroglyphs because no one can understand his lecture notes. He also doesn't know how to teach students the material in a coherent way, so you are on your own to actually learn the course material.
Get ready to read a third graders writing. It seems like this man writes with his left foot. You may or may not actually learn what will be on the test but you will for sure get sick of his "mkays."
Good luck reading his lecture notes. His hand writing is unreadable, and he loves to scribble over his already sloppy diagrams.

Extremely difficult to understand, cultural barrier (at times rude or socially inappropriate) and rushed through content. Course was held over zoom, so this mode compounded the existing communication issues.
Terrible lectures. She was very difficult to understand because of her pronunciation and she was unhelpful and uncaring outside of class. I do not recommend this professor at all

This is the most difficult class I have ever taken. The weekly homework was incredibly overly difficult. The exams were way too hard. Dr. Lau's lectures were hard to follow at times, but were overall pretty good. She threw in a lot of jokes. They were almost all recorded, which was nice in case I missed one.

This class is suffering. I don't recommend Lau because she doesn't make PowerPoints and doesn't ever cover conceptual questions, which is the main type of questions on the midterms and final. She does post all of the lecture notes and recordings which is nice. Also not helpful with class concerns and redirects you to Ziegler. Low class averages.

Dr. Lau is a genuinely caring professor.  She gives many examples in class, but unfortunately, those are hard to relate to exam and HW questions for intro-level students.  The class itself is absolutely atrocious, that is of little fault to her, though.  The course itself is designed by a manager who has no respect for students or professors.
Her lecturers were awful. Half the time she would skip through fundamental elements of questions and never explain the content. Although she was a good person, her lectures were really bad.

Professor Lau is a caring person but I felt her lectures fell a little short. Sometimes it was difficult to understand her and I felt like the explanations for everything were okay but not great. If you end up with her she's not a bad professor like many of the intro physics courses but not the best either. I'd rate 3.5 if possible

Funny lecturer and a caring professor. Don't be afraid to ask questions if you don't understand something. She can be difficult to understand at times, but usually asking for clarification helps. There is quite a bit of homework though.

She's not the most organized/clear lecturer and occasionally had to pause in the middle of doing a problem to fix serious errors in her work. That being said, she really listens to the class and actually re-explains stuff if the majority request it. When class went online, she was accommodating and made herself extremely available. Ask questions!
Honestly a pretty good professor in-person. Extremely kind and occasionally throws in a few jokes during lectures. A bit hard to understand at times, but overall pretty fair.

I don't know why there are not many students choosing her. But I would say that she is the best professor I have ever met in my whole physics courses. She has the most fair difficulty exam, and everyone who studies is going to get good grade.

Professor Lau is a genuinely kind woman, but unfortunately her class was a nightmare. Lectures were a waste of my time. I ended up relying on the textbook, Kahn Academy, and my stellar TA to pass this class. Her exams varied widely in difficulty between sections. My section's(Lecture time's) exam grades were 15-25% lower than other lecturers exams.
sucked with his lectures, only reason I passed was my bc of my TA
He can not reach. Nothing ever makes sense. Don't take his section if at all possible.
Definitely knows the content, but has no idea how to teach

I took 1250 with Dr Kilcup and enjoyed his lectures, he seems like a fun person and when you talk to him, he is always eager to help. I think he is far too smart to be teaching introductory physics so concepts that should be fairly straight forward tend to get complicated more than they need to be. If you don't have a good grasp on calc good luck.

He's a horrible lecturer. Explains the easiest concepts in the most convoluted way. Wastes a third of the class time by getting sidetracked on stuff. If you take him, be prepared to put all your time into self learning.

Dr. Kilcup is an incredibly smart man however he does not convey this into his lectures. He talks about inconclusive items that have no correlation to the concept being taught and is overall a waste of time. Lectures feel like they are dragging. While he is a great guy I would not recommend taking a course taught by him as you will feel lost.
He does not care for the students that he teaches and does not explain concepts well at all.

He is so slow when he is teaching and he does not know how to convey and explain any concepts. Please if you can, do not take this teacher, he keeps bragging about how he's friends with Bill Gates and not caring about teaching us physics. You have to teach yourself everything.

He is very bad at teaching, he never does practice problems and just reads off slides The top hats he does is just for participation and he does so much he ends up forgetting the point of the lecture that day You will have and must teach yourself everything

Does not teach well at all, only reads off lecture slides. This is a tough course with lots of math around it, so its surprising that he does not ever work out any questions within the units. Does loads of TopHats with each lecture, and does not even explain how to do the questions and just moves on. You will have and must teach yourself everything

Really smart guy but I couldn't learn anything from him after the second week. Be prepared for online HW to take 3-6 hrs a week and extra work given. Midterms multiple choice are worth a lot of points. Be ready to teach yourself everything unless you took some AP physics in high school. Takes attendance with Tophat questions unrelated to tests orHW

I kinda like him. He's a very chill and humorous guy. He replies to emails frequently and usually within 12 hours during weekdays. The whole class was not very difficult, the examples he gave in the class were enough to do well on the exams.
Does not give any examples with helpful instruction. Top hat runs the class and he is unable to explain any questions clearly. Switch out while you still can.

Extremely boring and melatonin inducing professor. He is addicted to top hat questions which he takes for your attendance and he doesn't do too many practice problems during his lectures. Instead, the time that he could be doing practice problems is filled with the time used by useless top hat questions.

I'm currently in his Physics 1250 class. It's hard for me to critique him a lot because he seems like a genuine and nice guy. But, I have heard from others, and learned from personal experience, that his lectures are pretty useless. He dumps a bunch of stuff from the textbook in lecture slides but doesn't actually fully teach the material.

Professor Kilcup is indeed very intelligent. However, when it comes to teaching, he is not the best. It is best to read the textbook than to go to his lectures, and the tests are graded very hard. I believe 1 multiple choice question on the midterm was worth 20 percent of the test. Try to avoid this professor of you can.
He is a very nice person, but I don't think he's the best at teaching. I had to teach myself everything in this class. Also, Dr. Skinner's slides were useful.

I like how he explained physics in a mathematical way. He is also nice person, always show up in his office hour Although his lecture can sometimes be tedious, typically a video and concept explanation and some top hat questions. I will try to read the text books before class and come to his office hour to get a good understanding.

He does not teach well. He expects you to know the concepts before hand, and then during lecture he doesn't solve problems all the way through, often times skipping important steps. He drones on in lecture and he never adjusts his mic so people can hear properly. I would recommend to do homework in lecture and then study on your own.

Lectures were pretty boring and not very useful. He knows what he's talking about but doesn't do a good job of actually teaching it. Weekly quizzes can be pretty difficult at times but the midterms and final were pretty reasonable and you can easily score well as long as you dedicate a decent amount of time to studying and doing practice problems.
Unique in his ability to make his lectures provide the body with extreme amounts of melatonin.

While Dr. Kilcup is indeed a nice person, and knows a lot about the concepts in his class, from my experience, he was not the best at teaching them. It was better to skip his lectures and just read the provided textbook. Exams were hard and required a very deep understanding of concepts that he just touched briefly in class.

Lectures were pretty useless, I only read the textbook and later read Dr. Skinner's notes. He makes the quizzes, and the averages are appalling. Exams aren't bad. Homework can be lengthy and they will help you in any way they can. If you are in his section, I encourage skipping the lecture and reading Dr. Skinner's notes instead.
Stay away from Kilcup, go to Brian Skinner's lectures.

I would not even bother attending lecture for Kilcup. You will have 2 minutes of a lead in video covering the topic of the day. Then 5 minutes of banter. The remainder of the class you will do Top Hat questions. Zero examples and he writes nothing down so his lecture notes are worthless.

Professor Kilcup was very rude, unhelpful, and seemed completely disinterested in teaching. I had to learn the material completely on my own, without going to class, as did most other students because his lectures were so disjointed, and unproductive. I think that what I experienced in this course is a terrible way to treat students.

The averages on his exams were about 10% lower than the other professor (Brian Skinner), who was awesome. He did not explain concepts well, and would not give practice problems. I recommend finding other sources to learn the material (not the book, it is useless). Brian Skinner posted lectures online, so try to use those.

Seems like a great guy but is horrible at teaching an introductory level physics class. He never had slides prepared so it was difficult to follow what was going on and he explaining things as if we already had a good understanding of the topics. Also, the lecture, group work, labs, and weekly quizzes never covered the same content.

Lectures are absolutely useless, and quizzes are impossible. Why do we use TopHat for 30 minutes to go over Python programming language and waste time looking at random machines when the actual knowledge required to pass the course isn't covered???

You get out strictly what you put in. Most of the learning is done outside of class, but Kilcup and the TAs are always available. Kilcup is a genius and there is a lot to learn from him, but his answers are indirect and make you think a lot. I learned so much from this class, but be prepared to do 10-14 hours hw/week. Count as 6 hr class, very hard

As a human being & lecturer he is amazing. An extremely important thing to note however, is that Kilcup uses the flipped classroom format, so be prepared to spend SEVERAL hours a week outside of class watching lectures. He is incredibly talented but because of this can be hard to keep up with at times. Always do your homework and you should pass

Hardest class I've taken, and I'm doing it again in 2301. Very difficult, but: lots of partial credit, many (5+) TAs for the class to help, Kilcup is very accessible, you're assigned a group to work with, & everyone (TAs, Kilcup, upperclass phys students, etc.) understand it's hard. Behaves more like a 6 credit hour class, NOT FOUR. (20 hr. hw/wk)

He clearly knows what he is talking about in class. However, he expects you to already know and have mastered most of the material. This "class" is more of a giant knowledge check than a real class. You get taught 10% of what you need to know and if you aren't solid on everything already then be prepared to spend most of your free time studying.

Dr. Kilcup cares deeply for his student's success. He is available for hours after lectures in the homework lounge and gives detailed answer keys to all homework and tests. His exams are brutal, but if you work hard there is no way that you can fail. It also helps Kilcup is a genius but friendly enough to approach. Work hard and go to office hours.
