I'm always confusing what he was talking about on lectures. Quizzes and finals are EXTREMELY horrible. Since he is the only one who teaches the courses, you are not probably avoid him. Be prepare to study tons of hours weekly and find that you learn nothing in the exams.

His fav statements: its clear where we got this number and you mightve made a sign error somewhere; its in fact NOT clear where we got the number and he NEVER explains how to correct sign errors. If his lectures were in person instead of recorded, these may have been easily remedied. He is smart, but clearly doesnt know how to teach.

Every email I have ever sent him, in both 2300 and 2301, went unanswered. Expect a ridiculous amount of homework, group assignments, and quizzes. Also his "lectures" aren't much more than re-voting on the same three questions on TopHat for an hour. Worst implementation of active learning I've seen. Only upside is the ridiculous curve he gives.

Professor Kilcup definitely knows what he's talking about, but often times it feels as if I don't. Most of his teaching is done outside of class in youtube videos he has made, and this particular vehicle for transferring information didn't work well for me. He is the only professor for 2300-01, but his methods make it hard to be enthusiastic.

Kilcup does spend more than enough time within group homework projects and will occasionally help you through the full process of arriving at the end result. As far as cons, he's not very accessible outside of class (I sent multiple emails requesting external help all of which have remained unanswered). He often insults students on the homeworks.

Unreachable. His method of "giving feedback" surpasses total incompetency as he consistently falls back onto one of his recyclable quotes such as "nonsense" or "it seems you have completely missed the point". Frankly, I have never had a professor so unwilling to tackle the responsibilities that come with teaching besides showing up to lecture.

This is a very frustrating class at times. There is a large amount of difficult homework, but Dr. Kilcup is available nearly everyday to discuss any questions you might have. The big problem I have with this class is the group work. As far as I am aware, absent group members are given the same grade as the ones who contribute. You will be alone.

The man is a genius. The problem is we are not. He has outrageous expectations for how much time we are supposed to spend doing his classwork. Expect 10 hours a week or more if you want to pass the class, double or triple that if you actually want to get a good grade. You can't fail this class unless you do nothing. Guaranteed C+ for minimal effort

Homework was incredibly difficult, I spent 10+ hours weekly on assignments.  He does not teach, but rather does practice problems in hopes we learn from those. Quizzes and exams were very difficult, mostly because we did not have enough time at all. He spent 3 hours daily helping students in the homework lounge, which was appreciated.

Dr. Kilcup possesses a wealth of knowledge like no other, however this only serves to exacerbate the frustration when he almost refuses to simply lecture; to teach even. He is too far removed from reality to realize that we haven't the physical intuition that he has. Go to class, participate, read the book, go to office hours, get TA help.

This class is a lot of work. But if you put in efforts and go to office hours, you will get a good grade. Dr. Kilcup is extremely generous about his time. He spends so many hours in office hours and group meetings to help students. I really appreciate it. Take less than 17 credit hours if you are taking this class.

He is nice, but being nice is not enough to be a good teacher. He attempts to use modern ways to teach his students by having them collaborate with each other in class and post lecture videos online, but it is executed horribly. He wastes a lot of time in class and his videos often focus too much on only a portion of the current topic.

He has us use an app and guess random physics questions instead of teach. If he does, it's some mumbling regarding the most basic example with nothing ever fully solved, but the exam questions themselves are brutally hard! Demands you write an essay explaining every problem and penalizes you even if everything is perfect otherwise. Egregious prof.

I have slightly mixed feelings for this professor. The homework assignments are very difficult and worth a large portion of the grade, but he is available outside of class, grades fairly, and encourages collaboration in the physics lounge. Lectures are of little use when it comes to learning material, so be ready to teach yourself a good bit.

The class 2300 is quite difficult. I learn best in the lecture and examples dynamic of a classroom, however he posts youtube videos of his 'notes' and does tophat questions in class. Most of the learning is done outside the classroom, and the homework and tests are very difficult. TA's are very slow to grade the HW's too.

Kilcup's class (2300 and 2301) made me fall in love with physics. This class is sink or swim: you need to be willing to learn to read a physics textbook to understand it. The days of being spoon-fed concepts are over. Kilcup is incredibly helpful once you've done the work of studying the material on your own.

About 40% curve for the class. Hard topics, book is dense, lecture is useless. I did almost none of the homework since I didn't know how to do them. Never got above F on a test. I didn't learn mathamatica because I didn't have a laptop to bring to class. Watching classmates work or text didn't teach it to me.

Probably the least structured class I've ever taken. Going to lecture was actually worth it maybe 40% of the time. He cares, he really does, but the class just makes no sense the way he explains it. In 2300, I never did the Mathematica work, got a C in Carmen, my final grade was a B+. I really don't know what grade to expect in 2301

Prof Kilcup is a great lecturer and explains the material very well. The midterms and final are definitely the hardest tests I've had to take so far, but if you put in the work and stick through till the end you will pass.

Without a doubt the worst professor ive ever had. Lectures are just rambling about random homework problems. Hes always available for help but if you try to ask him a question he only recites whats in the textbook and then keeps rambling about homework problems. Be ready to teach yourself literally all of the material.

Fall 18. 2 assignments a week. Expected students bring a laptop to learn Mathematica. Homework is difficult and long. Seems to care about students. Lecture taught me nothing. Book is too dense to understand. PDF is free, but I can't drag my desktop to ask questions or do Mathematica in class. Massive curve got me to pass without getting half of it.

I would've failed 2300 with any other professor. He is very concise, clear, and connects material to real life. He is very available as he is in the lounge almost every day. When asked a question, he often inspires you to reach the answer on your own. This is the hardest class I've taken but the best instructor.

Literally a great person all around. He's super friendly, and cares about all of his students. Only small complaint is that the man is a genius, and sometimes doesn't realize that the complex math and physics we constantly do in class may be easy for him, but not your average person.

Best professor I've had at Ohio State. Class truly teaches you to problem solve by working at needlessly hard homework with all your classmates in the lounge. Completely different from most classes in a good way. When it comes to actually 1 on 1 teaching no one can touch Kilcup's explanations.

This class with this professor killed my passion for my major. Lecture is useless; he either spends time giving partial solutions to homework or going off on some unrelated tangent. Going to office hours is incredibly unhelpful, and I emailed him my struggles and he told me essentially to figure it out myself.
this teacher uses the old way, and not clearly show us the way to do. He just simply explained the homework and did nothing better

All-in-all, Kilcup's class is about problem solving. His lectures aren't great, but he spends multiple nights every week in the lounge answering questions for and helping with concepts. Great guy and great teacher. The class was stressful and extremely difficult, but I've come out a better physicist, and that's thanks to Kilcup.

One of the greatest problems in this class is that a lot of students absolutely refuse to go to extra study sessions which Professor Kilcup graciously (not sarcastic) spends hours of his time helping his students with the extremely difficult homework. I guarantee that this will be one of the hardest classes you take, but it is not hard to get A's.

Professor Kilcup is awesome. He's not great at lecturing but he's so good at teaching, and will genuinely want you to learn the material. I have not had a professor like this until this day that cares this much. Truly and exception and smart man, I highly recommend taking this class with him. It is hard however, I have just worked hard nonstop.

Professor Kilcup's class is awful. Lectures are practically worthless, he will only cover extremely basic examples or go off on some unrelated tangent. Be ready to not understand what he is talking about. I have yet to meet a physics major of any level here who enjoyed this class. Don't be fooled by good reviews of him on here, they are outliers.
Really helpful out of class.

Simply put, Kilcup is an amazing teacher who cares about his students.  He is often in the physics lounge and goes out of his way to help students.  Some of the material may be confusing at first, but after talking to Kilcup, you will understand it perfectly.

Be prepared to learn the material on your own. He goes over the most basic sample problems in the lecture and the rest you have to learn on your own through the homework. The tests are extremely difficult. This class killed a little piece of my soul.

He only goes over the most basic example problems in lecture, never teaches beyond that, never answers email, tells terrible jokes, and goes on long useless rants when you ask him questions (sometimes he answers the question too). Get ready to teach yourself everything because lecture is useless and the homework is hard.

Dr. Kilcup is one of the best educators I have ever met. Lectures are good introductions to new material, but working on the extensive homework sets is where the real learning happens. Dr. Kilcup is extremely dedicated to his students. Getting help from him in the physics lounge will help you really learn new material.

Absolutely wonderful. The lectures are helpful but not always completely clear, but he is always willing to explain it to you until you understand completely. If you put in effort and ask him for help when you need it you will do well. One of the best professors I have ever had.

Amazing Professor. Probably the smartest man I have ever met. Rigorous course, but you will learn to truly analyze problems instead of just marching through them. Assigns on average 9 homework problems a week, and you will spend at least 9 hours a week working on the problems. Midterms will seem brutal, but you won't do bad if you put in the time.
Very hard class but Kilcup is an amazing teacher. He is extremely dedicated to his students and spends hours of his free time helping people one-on-one

Great person & best explainer I have ever had. Spend 45 minutes with him (which he will do without hesitation) and you will completely understand any topic. Like someone else said- you will understand physics, not memorize it. He also taught me universal strategies for attacking problems. Homework is a lot, but physics requires practice.

Kilcup is the most dedicated teacher I've ever had.  The material is hard on purpose but the tests are graded generously and you have a lot of leeway and bonus credit with the homework.  He doesn't so much lecture about physics concepts as he does about the mathematical methods of physics.  He enjoys helping and has unending patience.
Kilcup is awesome!  Class can be very difficult, but he is a genius and is always willing to help on homework.
Great guy and is very helpful. The class is intense and nearly impossible to understand completely.

Kilcup is awesome. If you are a good student in this class, you should do alright. The biggest reason I didn't do better was because I slacked on the homework. This isn't introductory physics, and some of the material is difficult to get at first. Kilcup is great at teaching you how to think critically and how to analyze problems properly.

Great teacher. Helpful lectures if you stay with him. Used Mathematica a lot and used worksheets to guide you along during math sessions. Terrific guy and always willing to help with HW, which could be pretty difficult at times. The exams were significantly easier than some HW problems.

Killa Kilcup is awesome.  The man is a genius and basically invented Mathematica.  Is always available to help out with any questions.  Homework load is a little much, but class is managable.  Great Guy.
He's straight killin 'em in classical mechanics.  Dude's a straight genius.  His class is tough but he's more than willing to help you with any/all questions.

I loved this prof. He was great to the extent of helping his students to fully understand the course. The grades were also fair. I really wanted to meet him again for the next two quarters. Don't get distracted by the bunches of homework he asked to do.

This is a tought class, expect to put in a lot of time into it each week. it is expected that you have a solid grasp of the material prior to taking this class. Dr. Kilcup is very flexible with meeting outside of class, and goes to depths to make sure you truely understand. Not too shabby overall.
Very smart man.  Can NOT teach.

This isn't an introductory physics course, so you are expected to already know something about the subject. Now you must "make it your own." This isn't accomplished by a prof holding your hand. Kilcup lets you find your own way, but his genius is such that he can find your errors in thinking. You will understand, not memorize, physics.

Coursework was difficult, expectations were above normal, but grading was very fair. Always willing to entertain questions, and always available, even for hours after class. Beware of 6 hour exams. No question is too great for the amazing Prof. Kilcup!

Kilcup is a very good teacher. It is clear that he knows and understands everything he teaches. However, he can be very hard to understand in one on one sessions. One piece of advice is to ask him any question you have. Even if its on a test, kilcup would rather you succeed than have the class kill you. P.s-rambling railroad is right...

Professor Kilcup is great.  He can be a little bit hard to understand at times (he thinks faster than he can talk and it throws him off) but he is easily the most helpful professor I've ever had.  I regularly see him stay after class answering questions for hours, outside of office hours.  I highly recommend him, he's a great professor.
really good teacher
I don't like Kilcup as a teacher, but as a person he isn't bad.  Take a ride on the Rambling Railroad, if you pass go collect $200.

Kilcup is one interesting dude! The course was very tough, but also very rewarding. Dr. Kilcup for the most part was very helpful and concerned about his student's performances. If you had a question, he tried his best to answer it. But you had to work in this class-it isn't a walk in the park.

Very difficult but rewarding class. Kilcup is rather eccentric in the way he goes about teaching; he jumps right into examples rather than giving a lot of explanation beforehand, but I found this helpful given the difficulty of the homework. Grading is fair for the most part.

I like his lectures, because he explains the material in a way that I can understand. This is extremely helpful, as physics can sometimes (or many times) be confusing. That being said, it is evident when he gets sick of students who come in to ask a lot of questions. Feigning support for students feels worse than not helping them at all.

I've been using youtube because the professor goes to fast in my opinion. his lecture slides make no sense so i use dave explains physics on youtube and its been a lifesaver so far. Prepare for hella worksheets and group activities and a lot of homework!

Energetic and patient guy. Seems very passionate about physics and genuine student interest in the subject. Lectures move quick and by themselves are insufficient to teach you the material, so you'll have to use the textbook. There is a good deal of homework, but that honestly incentivizes students to look at physics every day, per Ohio State rec.

She's a nice professor, and I think I took her class on her first semester at OSU. She rarely finished content on her lectures - sometimes we only got through 5 slides. She took a lot of time on problems in class. The tophat questions were good practice for exams, which were very easy. I took AP Physics 1 in high school, so I did fine overall.

While Dr. Chini is a nice lecturer, her lectures spent too much time covering material from the textbook that wasn't super relevant to the exam (although I already took AP Physics 1). In lecture, she only covered very basic questions, which did a poor job at preparing me for exams created by the department.

Chini is very nice and sweet, but not a great lecturer. She doesn't really explain topics, she just shows her work on the whiteboard. If you took AP physics 1 in HS, you should be good for the first half of the semester. Otherwise, I would use any help from your TA you can get.

Her class atmosphere was good, but the preparation was not sufficient. Sometimes she would make mistakes on the questions, which resulted in unclear knowledge.The slides in class went by quickly, and sometimes I couldn't understand the knowledge points well. However, this was her first year at OSU, so I could understand.

She is very sweet but unfortunately I did not learn much from her. It always seemed like she was unprepared, would run out of time, didn't know how to do the problems, and would frequently make mistakes. She also did not curve our class at all! I have some sympathy as it was her first year teaching at OSU but this class was a trainwreck.
Lectures often missed important concepts, she seemed somewhat unprepared. Tests are graded weird, few questions worth a lot of points. Took extra credit away, even from the students who did it.

Lectures were hard to follow. She posted lecture slides but they were unfinished. Went to her office hours but sometimes it seemed she was even confused on the material, which is unsettling for a student who also doesn't know what they are doing. She ended up taking away the extra credit at the end of the semester bc “not enough students did it”.

Dr. Yang was one of the best professors I have had at OSU! The class was hard, but his office hours were very helpful and his lectures were interesting! The quizzes are only 5 questions which is stressful, but he based them off of the online homework, so if you study that you're golden!
Caring, down to earth person. Cares about the success of all of his students. He will go above and beyond to help you in this course. Utilize his office hours!

Great lecturer but only covers basic material and expects you to learn the rest through mastering hw. his weekly quizzes are a lot easier compared to other professors since it's exactly like the hw. Outside resources are honestly more useful for this class.

Nice person but his lectures were long and usually pointless. His lecture slides were nonexistent, and he would just write on the chalkboard without checking in with the class. Very clear he's here for research not to teach.

Dr. Yang was a pretty good professor. He did disappear for about 3 weeks in the middle of the semester, but the exams and quizzes were all very fair. The questions on all tests are very similar to the Mastering homework, so as long as you understand the homework, you will do well.

He was a really nice lecturer and always made time for extra office hours if you needed help. Doesn't offer recordings of lectures, so make sure to go because weekly quizzes ar every lecture-heavy. The class itself is difficult, but he made it understandable with how he simplifies problems. Quizzes were a little tough at time because of timing!
He's a really good lecturer and a nice guy. Knows what he is talking about and truly tries to be available for questions.

Fine lecturer for 1200. Rushed through the material a little bit which forced me to teach myself in a few areas. Definitely wanted to see us succeed. His quizzes were fair and had few surprises. Taught the basic material well but didn't do too much more than that.

Professor Yang is such an amazing professor as well as a kind human! He is always available to help students in office hours and makes sure that they fully understand the concepts. 100% would recommend him to anyone for 1200! :)

Dr. Yang was amazing! He is so down to earth and did an amazing job clearly explaining the material. I have never taken physics before and he did a good job at speaking to an audience that may or may not have background knowledge in physics. He has such a good attitude and is very caring.

I feel like he did not explain topics thoroughly enough, but the amount of material required by the physics department is more than time allows. Dr. Yang truly cares about his students and is very helpful when you ask him questions.

Professor Yang is awesome. His lectures are very clear and has examples that are very similar to exam and quiz questions. He happily answers questions, and always explains concepts well. I took Physics 1200 fully online due to covid, and I feel like my understanding of the material wasn't affected in any way by the situation.

Dr. Yang is the best science professor I have had at OSU. He is very knowledgable, and he does a good job of explaining the material. He has interesting demos that keep your attention. His quizzes can get tricky, and you may feel rushed on quizzes/exams, so move quickly. Overall, a solid professor who cares about student success.

If you take Dr. Yang, go to lecture!!! He is fairly good at explaining difficult concepts and if you try to only use the textbook, you could miss vital details. Dr. Yang is clearly super smart but doesn't flaunt it and takes the class at a good pace. He always answers questions with tons of clarity. However, sometimes the quizzes get pretty tricky.

Dr. Yang begins the course assuming you have zero prior knowledge of physics, so every concept is explained very well and in-detail. He does a lot of examples which are extremely helpful. He always stays after lecture to answer questions, even to hep on homework problems. However he writes all the notes/examples on the board so they're not online!

Dr. Yang is one of the best and most caring physics professors at OSU. He is easy to understand and is willing to answer any questions. Even better, the guy is a total genius, but he's the most down-to-earth person I've ever met, which is hard to come by in OSU's physics department. I would definitely recommend taking Dr. Yang's class.

Dr. Yang is awesome. Super funny and helpful guy, he has great examples and makes physics lectures interesting. One of my favorite lectures at Ohio State. Make sure you take his class if you have to take Physics 1200. Class is hard, but if you do all the work and study hard then you will do fine.

Quizzes were not that bad (open notes) His lectures did not really prepare me for  the exams though. The book is better. If it wasn't for my TA Robert Patton, I would not have passed the class. My advice: get robert as a TA and GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS! I was getting 3/5 on quizzes but then with robert's help I was getting 5's mostly (a couple 4's)

Yang knows his stuff! He is very clear and his demonstrations in class are really cool. His exams are really basic and frankly easy if you study so if you put in the time you definitely will get an A! One of the best professors I have had so far definitely recommend

He explains concepts well, and the demos are pretty entertaining, but I always felt like I never had enough time to complete the exams. I feel like you need to be a good test taker to do well. Quizzes weren't too bad and labs were easy though. Homework assignments were also good for understanding the concepts.

Physics is a tough subject, but Prof. Yang is one of the best professors in the department. Very willing to help students; midterms and final were very fair. Be sure you know how to do the lecture, homework, and quiz problems, because he reuses variations of these on the exams.

His exams are harder this semester. We got a curve. I showed people who took him before and they were shocked at the difficulty of our exams, but if you suck at physics you should still pass in the B range, MAYBE C worst case. Quizzes aren't bad. Exams (including the final) only account for 55% of your grade. The other 45% is easy points.
Always clear and was sure to provide difficult examples in class with full explanations of the answers. Wish I would've taken him for 1201.

Dr. Yang is one of my favorite professors. He is a great lecturer. He is more than happy to help you do well in class. I went to his office hours several times and he was very helpful. Sure physics can be hard but to get an A in his class isn't hard at all as long as you do practice problems from homework and from lectures.

I loved Dr. Yang. He was very enthusiastic and did a lot of demos in class to keep you awake. He related the class material to real world situations so it made retaining information easier. The class is not too difficult but since a lot of people do well there isn't a curve. A few of his exam  problems come from lecture notes so make sure you go.

Dr. Yang is great!  He gives tons of examples in class.  Sometimes concepts weren't as clear, but I googled some definitions.  The tests are very fair as long as you do practice problems.  Dr. Yang want you to do well and averages were usually about 80.  The distribution of quiztest points was annoying.  MC was 5 puts each, all or nothing.

Dr. Yang was a solid professor. He provided all examples in class during his lectures and also was extremely fair. His quizzes were not hard and test were extremely fair. With some studying you can do well in this class. I would definitely take him again.

Dr. Yang is a very good instructor. His lecture is full of example's and demonstration. If you follow him step by step, you will be totally fine for quiz and exam. The homework is tricky sometimes, but you can ask for the hard questions during recitation. BTW, he has great sense of humor, some demo in class are very funny.

Dr. Yang's lectures were extremely clear. The textbook was only used for practice problems in recitation. His experimental demonstrations in lectures were helpful and quizzes and exams were very straightforward. He kept my interest and physics is still a favorite subject of mine.

Out of all the science classes that I have taken, Dr. Yang is my favorite. His lectures are full of jokes and he keeps your interest in what he's saying. Exams are very fair and straightforward. As long as you do the homework and understand it, you will do fine on both the quizzes and the exams.
His lectures are interesting and he provides great examples! If you attend lecture and read the book, you will do fine in this class. His exams are fair and he is willing to answer any questions

Great guy, but only does examples problems in class. Hw is straight from the book and can be very trickery. Exams can be easy but almost always has the trickest questions. For quizzes only have 20 minutes to take for 5 questions with heavy math so you will prob run out of time. Questions weighted heavily on exams too I had 1 question worth 10 PTA
Very good teacher. Explain on class is helpful. Sometimes very humor.
He's a good teacher who tries very hard.  I definitely learned quite a bit from him.  However, he's very monotonous and boring.  I fell asleep several times in his class throughout the semester.

Personally, physics is torture, but the way he presented the material definitely helped. He uses alot of demos and is pretty clear in explaining most concepts, so I really only had to use the book a few times for some topics or if I missed a lecture. Really go over the quizzes and homeworks because they help when studying for the final.

Professor Yang is very well spoken and a very interesting lecturer.  His quizzes and exams cover exactly what he says they will and if you understand what he goes over in lecture it should be an easy A.  There ended up being no curve in my class due to high averages a.k.a. everyone was well prepared because he is a ****!

Coming from someone who hates physics, this teacher is really good and he actually makes the class interesting. He does a lot of demos in class, which are sometimes even cool.  He is very clear with his notes and his quizzes and tests are straightforward and fair.
Great guy, great professor. Class isn't too difficult, and this is coming from someone who has never taken physics. Recommended.

Yang is a great professor. He explains everything and he explains in detail examples that he gives you in class and then they're on the midterms/exams! Book was no help. I had him for lab, recitation, and lecture and he really wanted to help you to understnd the material

Lectures were as interesting as they could be (it's physics after all).  He explains things clearly in lecture, but the online homework can be confusing at times.  His example problems are really helpful (and hints towards what will be on the exam).  Also, I found it helpful to review quizzes for the midterm and final.
made physics easy to understand great sense of humor lectures fun to attend

He was great on helping in and out of lecture. Quiz, mid-term really help in final exam. Online Homework is the key to success in this class, do not copy from others. Just try to work on yourself, than you won't have any problem getting B or above.

Exams and quizzes are much harder than the homework and don't follow any of the examples done in class.  He is sometimes very unclear about the material as well.  However, he is very helpful when you ask questions.
nice guy, but the exams always find ways to trick students. nice curve on midterms!
very helpful in and after class.
In the beginning of the quarter he went a little fast, but slowed down later and made everthing clear. Always very helpful in answering questions. Great demonstration. Tests are fair. I enjoy it.
Don't get much from lectures, but gives easy tests.  Read the book and you'll be good.

I've taken 24 QTRs of Classes at OSU (3.51 cum) this class ranks toward the bottom.  Class demonstrations are the best part about his class.  However, he doesn't speak very clearly -says WECTER instead of VECTORS.  He knows his material but has difficulty teaching the material.  Labs were useless
This dude is the hardest grader. I try to get help and never get any help from this dude. He grades so hard and comments the same thing but won't ever help me.

This professor needs to retire. He often soliloquized and ignored students when they raised their hands with questions. What he taught and what he expected his students to know were highly incompatible. I felt helpless knowing I had to learn the concepts on my own. This class is a pain.

Dr.Bolland is a nice guy, but his lectures are horrible. They are all over the place and make no sense and often he falls behind schedule. The quizzes were hard and the exams were even harder. I had to drop and get a W to preserve my GPA and I know a lot of people who did that as well. Avoid at all costs, there are much better physics profs at OSU.

Dr. Bolland needs to retire. He regularly loses his entire train of thought, and mumbles into the board instead of talking to the class. He makes his own quizzes and decides that his section doesn't need formulas. He doesn't answer lecture questions clearly, possibly because he can't hear what you're saying. This whole course is a nightmare.

The has been the worst faculty experience of my life. Professor Bolland does not know how to use technology and no one can hear him during lectures; aside from that he does not teach anything related to the homework or quizzes we receive. Overall this was a terrible experience PLEASE DO NOT TAKE 1250 WITH BOLLAND!!.

Dr. Bolland is a very kind man but his lectures are not great. He quickly switches from one topic to another and sometimes spent over half the lecture deriving equations, even when this wasn't something needed for the class. His quizzes weren't as hard as some other lecturers but definitely were not easy.

He is a very nice man but has some serious flaws for an introductory course lecturer. He skips a lot of important material, which makes the homework extremely difficult to impossible without looking up a tutorial on how to do the problem. Avoid this lecturer as unless you have extensive background knowledge, this class will be extremely difficult!

This would be a fine choice if you took an excellent high school physics class. Otherwise, steer clear of this class. Lectures were pretty useless, go to Lu's section instead or take 1250. They expected the avg grade on the final to be 40% or lower class-wide. This section brought it down. The curve is extreme, and the syllabus is VERY outdated.
I love Dr. Bolland, but please, if you are not a physics major, don't take this class. it is hard.

Read the textbook because going to lecture will be a waste of your time. He is a very funny guy, however his teaching style is very fast paced and covers a lot of things that are not necessary for doing well on the exams.

Bolland loves physics, but falters at teaching it. He often forgets that he is teaching to students with little physics background and neglects to define important variables/topics assuming that students already know the material. As someone who had a strong physics background and was successful in the class, his lectures were tough to sit through.

While they've improved it seems over the years at lecturing, they've still got a while to go. He assumes you know EXACTLY how to do everything before lectures and can master it within a week. Tests are very difficult if you had any difficulty on the homework. Take Physics 1250, it'll save you a headache, plus you'll learn much more smoothly.

Bolland is a very hard lecturer. He assumes you know what is going on. In order to succeed in the class, a lot of studying and extra work is required to understand topics. This is a very very difficult course. If you have any control over it, do not take this class with Bolland as your professor.
A genuinely nice guy who clearly cares about his class, but does not always convey content clearly. Recitations help a lot in learning the content
Dr. Bolland is extremely knowledgeable, however his grading system, and test design philosophy is... unique

I really want to love Dr. Bolland as he is the classic old wacky physics professor, but he's just not a good Professor anymore. Very nice man, and he loves the subject matter but that leads to him getting too excited and forgetting exactly what the lecture is supposed to cover. Exams are crazy difficult unless you study really hard.
Brilliant man, but only followed what he was trying to say based on taking AP last year. Doesn't answer questions very well, but is open to office hours even if they're not 100% helpful.

I believe he is a very smart man but he doesn't really know how to teach people who don't understand the material.  Class is difficult but doable, lots of points from homework and lab to help cushion your grade.  Labs are pointless but easy points so go to them.
Keeps you interested during lectures. Exams are difficult but manageable (Physics 1260)
Took 1251 with him. Hard class and he makes it harder. Lectures were terrible and not informative at all. Organic Chemistry Tutor and the textbook will be your real professors.
Learned a lot more from Organic Chemistry Tutor than his lectures
He's alright. Explains things pretty well but the class itself is just really hard on its own
Horrible lecturer, handwriting is unreadable and lecture examples arent comparable to midterms or homework
The Bock gets a really bad rep, but he's not THAT bad. Lectures have a tendency to put you to sleep, but he knows his stuff.

The homework is genuinely impossible without chegg but its the same for all 1250 students. I really did not think marc was bad at lectures. A bit of the way through the year he started giving us the answers to 1 quiz problem and 1 hw problem. Every recitation there is a quiz. Marcs quizzes are probably 2nd or 3rd hardest out of the different profs.
Recommend against

I had lectures online for Bockrath and his lecture were very unhelpful. You can barely read his handwriting, there is no organization with his notes, and honestly, the lectures are just not helpful. I just watched Youtube videos and read the textbook to understand the concepts.

I'm glad I waited to write this review. The semester started off horribly, and the class had to come together to report several flaws to the head of the Physics dpt. His lectures aren't great, but if you've read the book, you should have no issues following. I wouldn't say lecturing is his strong suit, but Marc is incredibly smart.

Bockrath's lectures were quite bad. A lot of the time he went over stuff that is insignificant to what we are actually quizzed/tested on. The weekly Web Assign homework was also hell, and you're forced to rely on Chegg and other online resources to get the answers because you're never taught how to actually solve the problems.

Mark Bockrath couldn't teach me what 2+2 is. You'll learn more physics watching the big bang theory than in any of his lectures. He doesn't even keep the TA's informed. He assigns homeworks due on Friday that is literally impossible to do without Chegg
Yeah, don't go to class, all he does is derive equations and write in unreadable handwriting. My suggestion is watch a lot of youtube and trust your TA, this guy simply does not care.

Bockrath is the type of professor that turns a class into an independent study. You can't read his writing and all the questions are out of the book. The other options aren't all that good either. The class design is horrible, constant quizzes and homework you can't get any feedback on and labs which are just a blackhole of 2 hours.

Physics 1250 is probably going to suck no matter what professor you have. That being said Professor Bockrath isn't good but your life isn't over if you get him. If you're having trouble make sure to go see your TA

He seems like a nice guy and he is also a smart professor but he sucks at teaching. 90 % of the lecturers are just him deriving equations or showing proofs and he spends very little time actually explaining the physics behind stuff. If you are in this class read the textbook and make sure to use outside resources to stay on top of the material.

If you think you know the material, think again. They test test you on things that you have never seen, and probably will never know how to do. You will leave every test feeling stupid while simultaneously crying. Have fun in the worst semester of your life.

He's a nice person but his lectures are rather boring- he works out one problem that really doesn't apply to most situations for the entire 55 minute lecture, most of what I learned from the class was in recitation and on the homework. His midterm averages were higher than other sections but his final was absolutely awful

Is very calculus based and will not give answers. Large focus on the derivation of formulas, although not necessary for class. Few demonstrations but most of the class was doing example problems. Will clearly answer any questions in class.

Bockrath isn't great, it's arguable that he isn't even good, but he's at least acceptable. He'll get through the material and places emphasis on where you need to study, but PLEASE actually DO THE HOMEWORK. If you can complete the WebAssign problems and lecture examples with no issue, you'll be fine. Bockrath will not help you through though...

If you have an affinity for math and physics this is your guy. 1250 is a CALCLUS-BASED COURSE and he embraces that. He doesnt have patience for students who want answers given to them. If you go to him with formulated questions that demonstrate you put thought in, he is very helpful. If you want to actually understand material he is amazing.

I went to lectures the first few months and they did nothing for me. He teaches very fast, doesn't explain anything, and never responded to my emails. I taught myself all of the material from the textbook and Youtube videos. If physics isn't already your strong suit, I don't recommend his classes!
Worst teacher on the planet. His lectures are a complete waste of time.
If you get a chance to take a class with the Bock, take it. Some people hate him, but all in all, hes a brilliant guy. If you can understand physics, he can teach it.
Oh My God just read the book he can't express anything.

Just read the book. I stopped going to class the last 3 months, and i got an A just reading the book once. It reads like a story, and its actually quicker to read then the total time u would spend in class anyway. Its literally that simple, just read the book and you will succeed.
The lectures are incredibly boring and unhelpful. He's so smart that he can't bring himself down to think on the same level as a freshman.
If you have Marc Bockrath, good luck. Be ready to teach yourself what you need to know, he does not like answering questions in lecture and provides little to no examples.
I recommend going to your TA hours every week and watching videos online over the material.

If you have Marc Bockrath... drop the class now. He is the worst professor I have ever had. I have never been more frustrated or confused by a teacher. You can not read what he writes and his passion is deriving equations. He also never responded to any of my emails does not care about his students and is the worst professor I have ever had. AVOID!

Bockrath is one of the worth teachers I've ever had. If you get him, don't bother going to lecture, it won't help you learn the material. He wastes a lot of time in lecture doing derivations that you don't need to know how to do. His example problems are impossible to follow and his handwriting is illegible. Avoid him at all costs.

Marc really likes doing proofs for everything so unless you have already taken Calc 3, you'll be lost for half of the lecture. He rarely does any applicable examples in class, and the ones he does do, he rushes through them. He definitely is a nice guy though, never has seemed arrogant or anything. Very approachable, but just not a good prof.

If you end up with Marc as your lecturer then I suggest you read your textbook to learn the material that will be on the quizzes and tests as he does not explain anything very well during lecture. Also, if you have a good TA for lab I highly recommend going to their office hours for questions on the homework

I did not learn anything during lectures. I did not take physics in high school so I went in clueless and the only way I learn anything was from the textbook and looking at examples from other professors. He spends lectures deriving equations and does not do a lot of example problems. He messed up on some of his own example problems too
I think not.
He describes concepts that dont really need to be described, and sometimes cover what is on the quizzes and tests.
Not friendly

Mr. Gan is a terrible professor. He turned Physics 3700, a compulsory graduation course for Physics/Astronomy majors, into a mediocre one. The final exam accounted for up to 25% without valuable review materials. He is very irresponsible in teaching but very strict in grading. Please choose Dr. Leonard's Physics 3700 instead of Gan's.

K.K. Gan is an evil. Physics 3700, a required laboratory course for physics/astronomy majors that is supposed to focus on operation rather than theory, set a single final exam at 25% and did not give any helpful review material. He was also not good at teaching, and I dropped his class after less than a month in the spring.
This is the worst professor I have ever had.

Final is 25%, notoriously difficult, and you're given no review material. Rest of class is not difficult to survive if you work with others. It's a required class for physics so it's really sad that so many students have to experience Gan's very poor instruction.
He's also a very disconcerting personality and makes many people feel uncomfortable.
Worst professor I've ever had.
evil.

Angel professor! She attaches great importance to interaction and feedback with students. The questions are appropriate and points are deducted for each student. The final score still has a big curve!

Would recommend taking Trivedi for Physics 1201 10/10! She posts great outlines and summary pdfs for every lecture, and clearly cares about how well students do. I believe her exams and quizzes are a lot easier than other Phys1201 professors. Her office hours are pretty limited, but she is very fair when it comes to grading.

Prof. Trivedi is one of those teachers who inspires you to do your best. The class was extremely hard, but after the initial "I hate physics" weeks, it became really enjoyable. Read the book. Her lectures are there to get you interested in the big picture. The book and office hours are where the real details are at.

An amazing teacher. She really clearly cares about her students and the quality of their learning. The class itself is incredibly difficult and requires your best (and so does she), but she's always willing to help you learn.
A really good person, who really cares about her students and how they feel.  This class is just really hard.  And it kinda sucks.

Probably the most passionate professor about their subject I've ever had.  She will go out of her way for students, and spends a lot of her free time for this class.  I thought the class was very difficult but I definitely learned a lot.  Very fair, and wants everyone to walk out with a solid understanding

She absolutely loves physics and loves teaching it. Clearly cared about us actually understanding and was helpful. She had a flexible schedule and made herself available for office hours often. BUT she wasn't exactly great at clarifying some of the stuff she tried to get across. use the book too and youll be fine though

Dr.Trivedi is hands down the best professor at OSU.  Her passion for physics is contagious and she is deeply concerned that everyone understand the material well.  She wants you to come to office hours to help you.  The class isn't easy, she's asks difficult questions but your intellectual capacity will be enhanced.  there is not a better professor

Dr. Trivedi is an amazing professor.  She is very interested in the subject and her love of physics makes you enjoy it way more.  There was 3 office hours a week, that I recommend attending, and she often held them longer than stated to help everyone she could.  She would much rather you learn for mastery than worry about an A.

Trivedi is very eager to teach.I had her for a lower level beginning physics class and she spent a lot of time and effort to make sure the class understood the basic principles.Very good with email communication but check before class to make sure you didnt miss anything.She will bend over backwords for you.  Cares more about material than grades.

Class is super hard and poorly set up (thanks to the department) but Dr. Kural does very well navigating that. His lectures are super informative, and he makes them entertaining. One of the best in the department.
Hard class but be you can tell he cares about the students.

Kural is a funny guy who gives pretty good lectures. He also likes to recommend strategies for students to improve themselves at the end of lectures sometimes, which is nice (one time he recommended "Atomic Habits"). The course is very difficult, though, so prepare to put your nose to the grindstone.

Professor Kural does a good job of creating a friendly environment during lectures. The class content can be very challenging and the homework's will require large amounts of time put in outside of class. This was my most difficult class but Professor Kural made the lectures engaging and interesting. He also seemed to genuinely care.
love his accent, made the class more enjoyable

The class is known to be difficult, and it is. I've enjoyed Dr. Kural's lecturers and he approaches difficult concepts in a way that made sense to me. Legitimately a good lecturer, makes lectures entertaining, and approachable in office hours if you need additional help. I recommend taking him as a lecturer if you can.

Physics 1250 sucks no matter what, but Comert makes it a little bit more bearable. He cares deeply about his students and is funny as can be. Sometimes he can overexplain some things which can make things even more confusing, but I think that was more an issue with my skillset. If you have to choose any professor for 1250, choose him.

Class in general sucks, but Prof. Kural gives great lectures, and is very approachable outside of class. He explains things very well, and is always open to questions. If you are taking this class, beware, it is actually awful. The homework is very hard and grade wise it is very test/quiz heavy. It is so important to go to lectures.

Professor Kural was a good lecturer for the class design. His lectures were always straight from the textbook which was nice and I found them pretty engaging. He even took some time in lectures to give life advice at the end which was a pretty funny but showed that he at least cared about his students. However, the online HW in the class is brutal!

Professor Kural is a funny and likeable person. His lectures involved flipping through pre-made slide shows. I feel like I mostly passed the class because of my background in physics, not exactly because of his lectures. I found the slide shows confusing and jumbled with many unnecessary equations. However, I enjoyed his lectures overall.

I like Professor Kural a lot, he's pretty funny and overall a great lecturer. Lots of demos in class (he even did the famous experiment, putting the pendulum against his head and letting it swing). But be warned, physics classes at OSU are extremely difficult, so be ready to do a lot of homework and attend your TA's office hours.

I literally hated physics before taking this class. Thanks to Prof. Kural, I now find it interesting and applicable to life. Overall, he really wants students to understand the material and succeed. The class was very hard but Prof. Kural was very engaging and knowledgeable and I am happy I had him.

Kural was enthusiastic about the material and made lectures exciting. Lectures mainly focused on conceptual topics, with less math, which made me feel unprepared for the majority of math-based group work and exam questions. But overall, I found the lectures interesting.

Physics 1201 sucks! It was one of the most intensive classes I've taken. But Kural is a fantastic instructor. He did a great job of explaining concepts and making the complex concepts much easier to deal with. I would definitely take him again.

Dr. Kural was a solid prof! His quizzes and exams are harder than his lectures, but the large curves (20-30%) make up for it. You really just need to beat the curve for a good grade. Make sure to go to TA office hours for the HW, do textbook problems, and study his groupwork and past quizzes well. If you put in the work, you'll be fine!

Kural was a good professor, but his tests were so hard. They ended up getting a large curve but I would rather have just gotten a good grade in the first place. He explains the physics fairly well, and if you reread the slides before the quizzes you should be good! He wouldnt be my first choice, but certainly not a bad one

Dr. Kural is a great teacher. He is very knowledgeable about physics and does a good job answering questions. The class is group work heavy and the majority of the assignment are graded on completion. The tests are super hard but there are huge curves.

Both midterm averages are 50%, but then curved to a 77%. Kural makes quiz and test questions extremely hard and youll gain little from studying his lecture slides. He has a complex where he doesnt like to repeat himself and can be very rude if you ask him to repeat anything. Wouldve rather taken calc based physics than have to deal with him.

Dr. Kural is the single worst professor I have ever had. He is terrible at making exams (told students that is GOAL was for the average to be less than 50%) and was not willing to listen to student complaints at all. Openly talked down to students and was downright rude. I would not wish his course or even knowing him on anyone. Terrible professor.

Professor Kural was ok. Make sure you use the lecture slides and you will pass. My biggest concern was the structure of exams and quizzes. Everything was multiple choice so no extra credit for showing work. Miss one question and it will cost you on his short quizzes and exams.

Dr. Kural does not foster a very good classroom environment or communication. If you are someone who often emails their professor with questions, don't even bother with this class. Extremely rude over email and office hours. Study 2+ days in advance for quizzes. Quiz questions are extremely difficult compared to lecture. Just learn from the book.

People have told me that Physics 1201 is the hardest class they have taken at OSU. I came into the semester genuinely concerned about it, but honestly it wasn't that bad. I attended lecture, took notes, and reviewed his lecture slides. Make sure that you understand all the concept questions that he puts on his slides. It really wasn't that bad.

Very difficult course especially if you don't like physics and have no interest in learning. You need to work real hard to stay on top of things. I think Kural made it enjoyable and relatable despite my struggle.

I wanted to add a review because it seems a lot of students are giving him a bad rep when in reality it is the course not the professor. The concepts and math in this course are definitely harder than gen chem or physics 1200 - this class sucks. As far as OSU physics instructors go I think Comert gives an honest effort and is well organized.

I tried really hard in this class and still did not do well. I attended every lecture, read the book thoroughly, and still managed to do bad on exams and quizzes. This class is really tough and if you are bad at physics like me, you will probably struggle.

Dr. Kural's 1201 class is quite difficult plain and simple. His weekly quizzes are very tricky and this class was a huge step up from 1200 in terms of how much I had to study. It's possible to do well if you spend the time and effort. Final is totally cumulative so prepare for that accordingly. Don't take if you have an easier option, he is rough.

Kural's quizzes and exams are difficult. You really have to understand the concepts and know how to do problem-solving beyond the simple examples he gives in class. We had very low exam and quiz averages, but with the median being relatively higher, the curves aren't great. I'd definitely suggest taking another professor.

I enjoyed this class much more than 1200, even though I thought I hated physics. Quiz and midterm medians are around 70%, so they were definitely fair. In my opinion the people who write negative reviews are just upset because the subject matter was difficult.

Kural is enthusiastic about teaching this course. The subject matter is inherently difficult but he makes it interesting and enjoyable. Quizzes were difficult but not impossible and the midterms were fair. I believe I learned a lot.

Just NO. Avoid at all costs. He is so unhelpful and does not tell you how to prepare for his exams and quizzes. I read the book and did all of the exercise problems and misconceptual problems and still could not seem to do well on his midterms and quizzes. This class made me hate physics and it is so unorganized.

If you think you can breeze through 1201 after having a good time with 1200, think again. Kural is relaxed in lectures, but his quizzes and exams are ridiculous. Simply, he doesn't prepare you enough. Coming from someone who crushed the chemistry department, I have never had more difficulty in a class before. Poor organization & unhelpful. Avoid!

This class requires more than what should be expected of you to even barely pass. I put in hours and had to read lectures and book chapters over and over again to even kind of know what I'm doing in order to prepare myself for his unnecessarily hard weekly quizzes. I wish I would have been told his quizzes are nearly impossible to do well on.

Dr. Kural is hard and doesn't really care about students compared to his research but I mean his class is doable and you can just read the textbook and skip class and you'll be fine. Amazing curves tho so just beat the curve!

so hard! all conceptual multiple choice questions and even the ones with math are conceptual. cares about students and is sometimes funny, exams are really tricky but this class is just ugh! good luck to all

Comert is a solid professor. He makes it clear that this class will take a lot of work to do well in, which it does. However, putting in a lot of work will result in a decent grade. Lectures are interesting and make sense, which is nice especially when it comes to more complex topics.

Dr. Kural truly cares about his students (even if it doesn't seem that way). He definitely has the toughest test and quiz questions so don't take him if you want the easy route. If you do want to learn, he is your guy. I didn't go to all of the lectures, but USE THE BOOK AS A RESOURCE FOR MATERIAL YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND and ASK HIM YOUR QUESTIONS!

Dr. Kural was a funny guy in lecture, but some of his explanations were hard to follow. I studied hard for every exam and still had lots of trouble in this class. I am bad at physics, but I feel like I knew the material well enough for a base level physics class, but still had tons of trouble.

I thought Kural was a good professor to give you the baseline knowledge to succeed, but you also need to put in a decent amount of work outside of class. I recommend using the multiple choice problems in his slides and really understanding these underlying concepts the night before an exam/quiz.

Dr. Kural makes physics lecture interesting and fun. You'll realize this when you have a guest lecturer. His quizzes and exams are difficult but fair. Utilize the online homework and practice problems listed in the syllabus to study for his tests. Your grade in the course will be dictated by the amount of time and effort you put into studying.

Dr. Kural doesn't do much hand-holding. He establishes a baseline of knowledge and practice problems, which is typically not enough to succeed on quizzes and exams. Lectures are funny and can be helpful, but work outside lecture is important if you want to beat the curve.
He is a decent guy, but as a professor, just not very fair. His exams are difficult but there is a curve. Definitely could have put more time into it but he could have also been more fair.
Eh, he's okay but it's a lot of studying.

I thought Kural was great actually. One of the better professors (you'll quickly realize this if you have a sub lecturer). Had good analogies in class. Also quick at answering emails. Clear that he wants you to do well. Most would agree that overall, the exams/final was definitely fair if you studied consistently throughout the semester!!!

No. If you have him for Physics 1201, drop and switch professors. He was so unhelpful and unprofessional when I went to him for help in the course. His quizzes and tests are over questions far more difficult and in depth than those discussed in class. I spent HOURS reviewing the textbook and homework's before each quiz. Good luck, you'll need it.
Kural makes lectures enjoyable.  Quizzes and midterms were mild, final was hard.  prayer,  reading the suggested pages in the book, and practicing the problems got me through this class!

I didn't like physics much but I really enjoyed coming to lectures. Comert made classes funny and interesting. He did a really good job of relating it to things students can understand and does it in a comical way.
Comert explains the concepts very well. Exams are fair. I really enjoyed the class...
It was a tough semester but I enjoyed physics for the first time. He is a fun professor, but at the same time serious about teaching....

Funny lecturer, gives examples in class so you'll remember them. You don't really have to go to class since he just goes over the lecture slides and puts them all online. The first 2 midterms are really similar to the practice problems at the end of each lecture and the past quizzes, but the final is super hard.

Hilarious professor. He has a heavy accent, but very easy to understand, didn't cause any problems. Midterms were easy, very similar to quizzes. Homework questions are usually a lot harder than the quizzes. The final is nothing like the midterms though, you really need to study. Overall great professor.

Most down to earth professor I have ever had. He is hilarious with make the class enjoyable. His explanation is also hilarious which help with understanding the topics. The two midterms were extremely easy. But Final took me by a surprise. So study your butts off for final.

While he is a funny professor attendance isn't necessary because he just read from slides that were online. First exams were exact copies of quiz and homework questions but the final was impossible. Average was 49% and my section received a 30% curve on the final.

Only reads off lecture slides. Slides come directly from the book but make no sense. You have to read the book to understand them. Midterms are hard but doable. The final was terrible. Unnecessarily hard and everyone walked out saying they guessed on 95% of the questions. How well you can guess on answers will determine your final exam grade.

Fairly funny guy without a thick accent. Final was unnecessarily hard and almost completely conceptual. Had a high A before the final. Final grade in the class will depend on how many students failed the final as hard as I did. Lecture isn't mandatory. If you don't understand the conceptschapter in the book, go to lecture.

Comert's lectures were NOT helpful to me at all. He goes over lecture slides from the book which is helpful but does only a couple example problems and skips over the practice probs way before you even have a chance to look at them. I started doing better on the quizzes when I stopped going to lecture. His test are hard no matter how much you study

He's very good at explaining in lectures and his exams are fairly difficult; however, if you look over practice exams, quizzes, and notes; he takes questions straight from them and tweaks them slightly

I think he is a good professor. He is funny and always has a few jokes to pepper in every lecture. His quizzes can be tricky; make sure you go over all the "concept test"  questions from lecture because more than likely they will be on a quiz andor midterm. Midterms are very fair and based on previous quiz and homework questions almost entirely.

Kural is a fun professor and keeps physics somewhat interesting. He likes to trick you, but if you pay attention in class and read his quiz questions carefully you will be okay. His midterms have the same concepts as old quizzes and homeworks just reworked.
Final was all conceptual.
He is a very fun professor. Uses example questions in class.

Arguably the worst professor of all time. Brought up his own liberal view of politics constantly. Showed no respect for anyone else's opinions. Spent the whole class explaining a problem a drunken toddler could have explained in 40 less minutes. Just a waste of time and disgrace to the university.

You need to understand that Terry does not show up to teach, he shows up to entertain. Easily the most unhinged professor I have ever had, which makes his lectures pretty fun. Once you accept the fact that you're gonna have to teach yourself most of the class, you'll like Terry a lot more.

To be successful here you need to participate in class. Ask ?s, watch Khan Academy videos, & attend his office hours. Not the best at email responses, but if you walk up to him after class with the work you have done to show that you are trying, he will help you. Read the textbook, do the textbook problems. Quizzes are hard, exams are moderate.

If you are among the unlucky souls to be selected for Terry's class, try finding another professor. If there aren't any, don't bother going to the lecture. He's too busy discussing bar fights, fish, and religion to focus on physics. Just read the textbook sections and save yourself a lot of time.

The other reviews about being disorganized are not wrong. If you have a good background of physics, you will be fine. Walker is kind and funny but does not teach much. However, all of his exams are pulled from the weekly quizzes, and the weekly quizzes are from homework material. If you follow the online homework assign. and quizzes, you'll pass.
Barely taught when he did have lectures. Towards the end of the semster, many lectures were cancelled. The class is very poorly organized.
Has a minimal interest in teaching.

Not a single lecture went by without Dr. Walker talking about a million different things that had nothing to do with physics. He was funny but he was not a good teacher and didn't care to fix that. Half the concepts had to be self-taught and the coordination staff was unaccommodating to the lacking of lecture. Boo

This class is so poorly organized and taught. The material taught in lectures almost never lined up with group works we were required to do in recitation. The TA's voiced many concerns about the difficulty of assignments and how even they as PhD students struggled at times but professor Walker never even showed up to the meetings.

In lecture, you have to follow his explanations which can be tough at times, especially when he goes on tangents. But he's very smart and if you ask him for help he's very accessible and willing. Additionally, his midterms and quizzes are straight-forward, the final was very difficult but that wasn't made just by him, and the curve was significant.

Questions from previous quizzes were word for word on the final (didnt even change numbers). Dont see how you could do badly in this class if you go to lectures and study what he says will be on the exams! The only thing that sucks is missing one question on quizzes takes you from a 100% on the quiz to an 80%.

If you have a background in physics from high school, and don't need to know it in the future, hes your guy. His exams are ridiculously easy and he is very clear about what exam questions will cover. His lectures are pretty mediocre, but he does make them entertaining and funny.

Dr Walker spends more time talking about other things than he does talking about physics. His lectures are confusing, and most of the time he tells you not to write anything down. Quizzes are mostly conceptual and missing one question on a quiz basically tanks your grade. Midterms are fair be sure to study everything. Try not to make assumptions.
Study conceptual questions if you take this guy and study what he says wont be on the exams because he puts it on there anyway. If youre stuck with him, good luck.

This class really made me work for my grade, but thats me personally. I went to office hours weekly and hired a tutor. He is extremely caring and he really wants to help you out in any way that he can if you get to personally know him. He is a great guy. The home work is tougher than the quizes and midterms, and the midterm curves were pretty big.

Walker is funny and when he's cracking jokes, it keeps you engaged in lecture. However, his methods of explaining topics is usually confusing. He would usually put exact questions on quizzes/exams that were covered in lecture. It's easier to learn how to solve problems from the book than from him, he is confusing. We got >15% curves on midterms.

Because of my physics background, I found this course relatively easy. However, I saw how it could be difficult for someone with little physics experience to learn from Dr. Walker. He makes every effort to give reasonable problems that students are familiar with on tests, but sometimes his efforts at simplification only complicate problems more.

Terry is a pretty bad professor at teaching, but makes it very simple to get an A. He just recites what's in his notes as fast as he can and throws in a few jokes (dry humor). But this is the most minimum effort science class there is with Terry, all you have to do is work hard until you know how physics works, and then its an easy A from there.
Terry is an awesome professor. His quizzes are pretty easy and if you study all of the homework assigned his tests are not too bad. He is really helpful if you meet with him outside of class.
really easy class, funny guy

If you have the option, do not take Physics 1200 with Dr. Walker. He is very sarcastic and rude during lecture. Often times he will spin off on a tangent and he rolls his eyes when students ask ' dumb ' questions. He takes the long way to do every problem in lecture, so rather than get through 4-5 lecture problems, we get through 1 1/2.

Worst professor ever. He was hilarious, other than that.. AWFUL. Was not good at explaining anything, at all. He gave off that "i'm too smart and cool" to teach this class. Actually admitted he didn't like the topics he was teaching.. If you HAVE to take this class, do not take it with him.
Understand the problems that he assigns and you won't have any problems.
Dr. Walker was a great professor. Certainly has the "too good for this" vibe but I loved his class. Tests and homework were a breeze. Definitely would recommend

Walker is hilarious so lectures at the very least are entertaining. He has good examples in class but often doesn't finish them. He actually does want students to succeed and do well, you just have to be willing to do a lot of work outside of class. The exams aren't completely unreasonable, you just have to practice tons of problems to keep up.

Walker has one pro: that he's freaking hilarious. Thats about it. He gives the "I'm too smart to teach this class" vibe, as well as the "you should already know this" vibe, even though this is the first Physics class. I don't mind the material being hard, since it is physics, but I learned nothing in lecture and only passed because of the textbook.

Very bad at explaining thermodynamic topics in the third section of the class because "chemistry isn't a real science" and then put multiple questions on thermofluidspressure on the final.  Made an offensive heil hitler joke and practically flipped off the class.  The actual course material was not bad, just a "too good to teach" professor.
Tells numerous jokes in class that are offensive. Doesn't respond to emails, and hard to meet with outside of class.
Walker's lectures are a lot of fun: they're hilarious, but he doesn't explain the material well. It ends up being confusing. I learned much more from my TA.

He is pretty good at explaining concepts and preparing you for his exam. His exams are very fair!! His exam problems come directly from in-class problems that he writes on the board and solves with the class. He's really funny too and willing to help you if you ask him. I would say the quizzes were kind of hard. Some homeworks  were hard too
Funny, but very inconsistent with variables. Skims through his process or with an incredible pace. Has an ego which can make approaching him difficult.

He is interesting in lecture but really doesn't help with physics at all which eventually led to me attending less than half of his lectures because quite frankly I had more productive things I could be doing than sitting in his lecture
very funny but he gets distracted a lot in lecture
Very funny guy, good professor.

Taught my physics 131 for honors engineers class. Instead of teaching physics, he practiced his stand-up comedy on us (I'm not kidding), talked about astrophysics (his research field), and generally acted like teaching this class was beneath him and a waste of his time.
Really funny so never fell asleep in class.  He taught using lots of examples and less theory, so if you learn by theory you may have a tough time. Really helpful if you go to his office hours.

Good guy, funny. Goes through some concepts fast, doesn't go through specific questions often. Makes sure you know how to apply the equations, doesn't use numbers often. Good in combo with recitation and learning from the book, but probably not easy without.

Very difficult class. He seems like he would rather be somewhere else. Granted, he's funny, but he doesn't teach too well. He glosses over things too quickly & doesn't give specifics but rather writes down a mess of equation. Also, he seems  scatterbrained when it comes to examples and forgets what he did in previous classes.

Good professor imo. He focuses mainly on the concepts and doesnt bother with details. can be hard to follow because he uses many approximations, but is helpful if you can catch him at office hours. has a good sense of humor and interesting stories. Has a huge ego. I enjoyed his class, but i also like physics quite a bit
Didn't give many examples, all the lectures wereslide shows. Exams were based on homework assignments.

Non-calculus based physics class that used scaling problems to explain how various forces in everyday sports effect different aspects about the sport. Dr. Walker kept the lectures extremely simple and used a lot of sports-humor to keep things interesting like "**** My Ride" discussions in the middle of terminal velocity explanations. Great GEC

Funny guy. I never fell asleep b/c of that, but I hated that he used an overhead that was hard to read. His explanations were pretty bad some days, ok others. This one day he thought he was doing a pretty bad job of explaining things, but he was actually doing ok. Another time he thought he was doing good, but was sucking. I don't know.

not very helpful, uses variables all the time in his examples and never finishes them.  writes out notes ahead of time on an overhead, so he tends to go fast.  not helpful in office hours either, kind of mean actually.  you'll do fine if you know physics in and out, otherwise be prepared to study nonstop

More interested in entertaining the class than teaching.  Examples very hard to follow...and rarely finished them.  Moves so so fast. Tests and quizzes consist of off the wall tricky questions.  I suppose you could get an A in this class if you devour your physics book nonstop...which isn't that great of a text to begin with. Run away!

Professor walker is one of the most funny people that I have every met. That being said he does not take his lectures serious enough and does not try to make them accessable to the average undergraduate student. He falls short on explaining topics and enaging the classroom.
Easily the worst professor I've ever had at Ohio State.

To be fair, I did get an A, but that was no thanks to Dr. Walker. I learned solely from practice problems and the textbook. Going to lecture was uncomfortable for me because of his jokes! Some were really inappropriate and over the line. I also didn't like when we got off topic when all I wanted to do was learn and then go home.

This is a professor who jokes about inappropriate things (like p**n). If you aren't comfortable with that, don't take him. I don't find it funny, but a lot of students seem to. Other than that, I think he's just like any other physics professor. Focus on the masterings and you should be good.
Prof Walker is really funny and his lectures are entertaining. In terms of physics, I didn't learn much from him. He doesn't explain things well and he always complains about his colleagues.

The worst professor I have ever had and it's not even close. His lectures are unfocused and sometimes the stuff he says is just flat-out wrong according to the textbook. His lectures honestly confuse me more than learning the material in other ways. Our grades are consistently worse than in the other sections.

While he can go off topic slightly, he always makes sure that by the end of lecture he covers all topics. He likes hockey so that was entertaining to talk about instead of physics. In office hours he is extremely helpful and make sure you actually understand why the answer is what it is. Highly recommend

If you are among the unlucky souls to be selected for Terry's class, try finding another professor. If there aren't any, don't bother going to the lecture. He's too busy discussing bar fights, fish, and religion to focus on physics. Just read the textbook sections and save yourself a lot of time.

Terry did a great job the first half of the semester but complains about administration so much that he doesn't review later topics in depth. Overall, he makes the tests and the quizzes and does a great job of being clear what he wants you to know and not know but doesn't teach very clearly.

My whole class was behind and getting worse grades compared to the other classes taking PHYS1200 because of this guy. His slides and notes he uses during lectures are impossible to understand and he doesnt finish an example, he expects you to finish it on your own. The physics department needs to do something because I might fail bc of this dude
Never never will take his classes again. This guy has no responsibility with his job.

Always teach materials after quizzes, use one class to teach lots of materials which should be taught in three classes. This Professor doesnt even want to teach at all! Never will choose his class again!

This class definitely was not an easy class for me. Sometimes it felt like the professor talked more about beer and football than he did physics. He was kind of funny but the talk about football was a waste of time, in my opinion.

Every lecture was treated like a joke with him constantly going on tangents about things not physics related. Explanations about problems were never clear and left me wondering when I'll ever be taught in the entire course. Claimed there would always be a curve and there never was one. If you can't teach yourself, pick a different professor.

Dr. Walker is a very funny guy, but not the best lecturer. He often gets off track and does not explain the content very clearly, but reading the book will save your life. I also had him as a TA, so being able to see him in person and not just online definitely helped. I'd probably have him for 1201 if he was teaching it, but he's not for everyone!

Dr. Walker was a terrible professor in my opinion. Don't bother going to lecture as he is always off track and so disorganized. You will do better just reading the textbook and practicing on your own.
