Easy to tell that he is a professor that was hired for research and that's it.  Awful lecturer with a very boring class.  Spends the entire lecture going over 1 or 2 examples.  With that being said, lectures are boring, but if you attend class, usually half of the quiz problems come from there which helps a lot.  Don't fret over bad quiz grades tho

Lectures are useless. I took AP physics in high school, and i passed his class with an A only because of that reason. Try to avoid having him as a lecturer unless you already have a background of physics.  If you get stuck with him, make sure you read the textbook, and make use of his office hours.

Lectures were unbelievably useless. Halfway into the semester the lecture hall was half empty. This is due to his inability to teach useful concepts during lecture, and instead wastes time solving one problem in 5 different ways. Honestly you are better off just reading the textbook yourself

Dr. Leonard is not a typical lecturer. If you are interested in physics, lecture will be fine. If you are taking this class only because you have to, this class will not be fun. His class seems very difficult but if you can crack his testing style in the first few weeks, you should be fine. Pay attention to they types of question he asks in lecture

Professor Leonard isn't a bad guy, and he isn't dumb he is incredibly smart and passionate about his research. But he is an awful lecturer that wastes time and teaches in an easy way out fashion.  The ideas of physics are much easier to teach so those are what he teaches and then proceeds to expect you to just understand the numbers also.

He isn't the best professor I have ever had. I wouldn't honestly blame it on him though. The class is just very tough and the physics department set people up to fail. It is a "weed out course" used to lower the amount of engineering students applying to their major. Unless you had a good physics professor in high school, this course will be hard.
It is definitely a hard class, and the professor's lectures do not help much. The professor is very willing to help outside of class though, which saved my grade.

This professor's lectures convey no helpful subject matter and consist primarily of deriving equations (as does the course) and are at least two weeks ahead of graded quizzes. Take Physics at community college for EM credit, not worth forsaking your GPA because you're going to come out of this knowing only slightly more than when you went in. CURVE

spends most of class deriving, and doesn't give any applicable examples. You'll learn mostly from the quizzes you take every week. Goes on rants that have nothing to do with what we're learning and loses track of the topic. I'd look for someone else.

It is clear he is intelligent but has a hard time getting his message across to the students.  Lectures are slow and only cover one example problem which are completely unrelated to the homework or the quizzes.  Avoid if possible

Knowledgeable about physics, however lectures were extremely useless. He often times spends an entire class period on one problem that does not help with the material we are learning whatsoever. You are better off just reading the book and not showing up to class. I've had friends teach me more about physics in two hours than he has in six weeks

He focuses mostly on theoretical rather than practical applications of just about everything. While this is good because you learn the actual physics behind things, it makes doing homework and problems difficult because you don't know how to apply any of the equations he taught you.
Very glad I did not have him for lecture.  Easily the most useless lab ever.  Ideas and communication completely unrelated to lecture and explanation of ideas was irrelevant.

Worst professor I've had. Ever. I've attended 3 universities! Lectures are poorly prepared, he does not follow the book, and does not offer help outside of class. Several times did not show up for his own office hours! Save your money and wait for another prof to teach the class you need.
Class is not too bad, lecture is useless just read the book and do the hw, midterm, final and quizzes all were fair

Dr. Leonard's lectures can be boring and unclear but he is eager to provide help outside of class. Though his class is much harder than the first two in the series, if you're willing to put in the time to study it isn't too bad.

In accordance with the previous two reviews, AVOID this guy! His lectures are boring and unhelpful for quizzes and tests. You can read the book and go to every lecture and you will still struggle. He talks a lot about the history behind the material and tests on it also, and it is not mentioned in the book. 1/5of final had history questions...

Rick is a great person but was shy and nervous during lecture all throughout the quarter.  His ability to teach subjects effectively is lacking but you can tell he is very smart.  Tests and quizzes were difficult and hard to study for.  Avoid if possible.

Easily the worst lecturer I've ever had.  Not only is he the least engaging speaker in the world, he actually sucks at delivering information.  How can someone so brilliant be so incompetent at sharing ideas?  Quizzes and exams are poorly written and reflect how out of touch he is with his students.  Avoid if you want a fair grade.
Good guy, good lectures, difficult homework, and tests with appropriate difficulty!

Outstanding professor! The lectures were well organized, with students doing practice problems and lectures interspersed well! Weekly homework is usually tricky, but quizzes and exams are open-book, so avoid being too complicated. Recommend him!

Very solid professor. Although Physics 2301 is very difficult, Mr. Boveia makes it very clearly. The homework is difficult, but the quizzes and exams are open-book and difficulty-controlled (The difficulty of the tests are controlled to not very high).

Boveia was a legend for how clearly he explained difficult subjects like rotation and relativity. The homework is very difficult and takes a long time to finish. He deliberately controlled the difficulty of the exam, and allowed us to open the book, and finally gave curve a friendly. Highly recommend Boveia!

cool guy, bad homework. 

open note exams very nice. 
If you see hurricane balls, run for your life.

Boveia was clearly interested in teaching and cared about his students even though he was pretty awkward. His lectures were mostly tedious derivations and you don't really have to go to his lectures/take notes as long as you read the textbook. all his tests and quizzes are open note and most people get an A.
I really enjoyed his class! I read all the chapters and went to lecture and did well in the class. Every test is open note.
Great professor but get ready to read.

Homeboy literally just rants about his job at CERN and expects you to know Calc III before you get to the class. 65% of your points in the class are just complex integrals. He's a fine person but he just rants about random things and doesn't teach so either read or fail.
He is a pretty good professor. He is humorous.

He's a really nice, approachable person. He's very smart and knows what he's talking about. He likes to make connections to things students will find interesting. Overall a good professor, and he wants his students to do well.
For his first time teaching the course, I thought he did a good job. He's a nice guy, and easy to understand.
Funny professor, makes class interesting, moves quickly so make sure you understand stuff before you fall behind and get overwhelmed
His lectures are very difficult to follow. He is a very educated man but I personally could not keep up with him. Physics is a difficult course, and he didn't make a lot of things clear.
Nice guy, but challenging course.

Andrew is a very solid professor. He taught Physics 2300 for the very first time, but I can feel the high level of his teaching! Our section is small and new, with only 20 people, which is different from the other two big sections, so I had the best learning experience during the semester.
Andrew is very good professor. He cares students very much. Although Physics 2300 is very difficult, he can make such a course interesting! Highly recommend Andrew!
A very solid professor. He makes Intermediate Mechanics I, such a difficult course very interesting, and the final grades curve a lot!

I understand this professor was put in a difficult situation but this was the worst class I have ever taken. He was completely unprepared for every class. He gave us nothing to prep for the exams and we had to rely on exam corrections to keep a good grade. Activity sheets every class and 3 exams and 8 homework assignments. Absolutely terrible!

I also had Andrew for both lecture and recitation and would highly recommend him. Andrew is very clear and concise about what he expects you to know. He also is very helpful, and willing to work with you one on one during office hours or outside of school. He is one of the professors I have grown closer to and helped me learn to enjoy physics.

I had Andrew as both a recitation instructor and a lecturer for Physics 1200. I thought that the material was not that difficult but I still worked extremely hard for a good grade. I really enjoyed having him and would 100% take him again. He was great at explaining problems one on one. Go to office hours and you will get a high grade!

The worst lecturer I have ever had at this university. He gives you the first step of the problem and then proceeds to say "I'll let you do the rest" then gives you the final answer. Does not teach in the slightest and does not seem to care at all. If it wasn't for khan academy and my recitation leader I would have failed this class tremendously.
Had him as a TA. Was very good at answering all questions I asked him. Would take again.

I had him for a TA for 1200 and hes great. I like the way he involves the students when he explains concepts and questions and doesnt just sit there and talk. Great TA, not sure about professor though.

The only issue I had with Andrew was that he does stuff without explanation; he made us do extra work in the textbook and change groups without giving us a reason why. He also didnt have a TA so it took a while to get grades back, so for a lot of things we didnt get feedback before exams. With that being said, Andrew is really nice and he cares.

1251 material is hard, but Prof Dougherty's tests are fair. Questions are the same as end of chapter problems, about average level homework difficulty. His lectures are well paced and he tells you what he expects you to know. Extremely helpful at office hours. His test averages were lower than some other professors but this just mean a bigger curve

Go to class if you need examples of how the concepts work. He teaches primarily through examples and doesn't go through the concepts as much, but if you just read the sections in the book beforehand it will make sense. Very available outside of class and he even was willing to meet on the weekends. Go to office hours, he'll make time to help you.
He is one of the coolest professor in OSU. Make everything clear and like to help his student. Take him!

Andrew was really a great TA. He is a little confusing in class b/c if the prof gets behind in the lecture he doesn't know that. But if you need help, he is more than willing to meet at a time that fits your schedule. He was so helpful and made a huge difference in my grade.

The lecturer was horrible and Andrew was a life-saver. He broke down the problems and made them easier to follow.  He was enthusiastic about physics and very willing to help! He even met with students outside of office hours! Not to mention he's easy on the eyes. I would highly recommend taking class with him! He's a great teacher!
He explains things really well--I wish he had been my recitation TA--and is just a nice, cool guy in general.

Very helpful, helped me understand things I couldn't in lecture with clarity I've never received from a physics professor or TA. Graded homework on completeness, not accuracy which rocks. Great all around TA regardless of the 1st rating.

Success in his class is determined by how closely you listen and apply what he says during class. Learn from the mistakes you make. He's very specific about the style of writing and presentations. The assignments won't be long, but they're research heavy. Overall chill, straightforward professor that listens to the requests of the class.

Honestly a good class, first few weeks goes over the basics of scientific writing and research then the rest is writing essays and presentations. It's a good amount of work but as long as you don't wait until the last minute (like me) it is very manageable class.
Probably the worst professor I've had so far. He's nice, but ridiculously unorganized. His lectures confused me more than just reading the book. Woild not recommend.
He does not really teach. Quizzes are different than the lecture most of the time.

Chris Hill is a good physics professor. His test averages were always higher than the other lecturers and I think that is because he has a very nice broken down way of teaching physics. It is true that many people left early during his lectures, however I never saw a reason or felt the need to.

Professor Hill is a chill guy who can be pretty funny and entertaining in lecture. He derives a lot but then he does do examples to showcase how to apply it. The quizzes are often difficult but the free response is typically similar to an example done in class. The class is still difficult but he is a good professor.

This review is of Dr.Gruzberg, not the physics dept. (separate convo) so this is only what he controls (lectures & supplemental material). His lecture slides are very organized, color coded, step by step, & provides lots of examples, also posting the lectures to zoom after lecture for review. After talking with others take Gruzberg for 1250 if can.

Physics 1250 is hard, and the OSU physics department isn't very good. Dr. Gruzberg is nice, but his lectures were very monotone and all he did was read off the slides. There are quizzes every Monday in recitation based on the homework's from the previous weeks. I'd suggest supplementing lectures by watching YouTube on subjects covered in class.

Gruzberg's lectures were very monotone and hard to follow. He created slides with practice problems that he thought could be useful but did not explain the concepts. I ended up going to another physics lecture with a different professor to gain a better understanding of the concepts. Overall, Gruzberg is a good person but a terrible lecturer.

The class itself is relatively difficult but manageable if it is given due effort. Ilya is a good person but not the best at lectures. He kind of just puts (hopefully relevant) equations up on the board and then moves on to the next thing. Lectures are not very mind stimulating.

This class isn't as bad as everyone says. Do your homework (there's not a lot) and show up to recitation and lab! This professors lectures are rough. He puts new information on the board and hardly explains it. You will learn more by doing the homework than by attending his lectures. Although, I've heard there aren't many great physics professors.

I went into this class already having a good physics base from high school, which is the only reason I did so well. His lectures are, frankly, pretty bad. His lectures don't help for homework / exams, and a lot of learning has to be done by yourself using the textbook and / or recitation and TA help. Beware if you're new to physics.
Horrible Professor. Avoid at all costs

Bolland's lectures are difficult to follow, he spends the entire class showing how to use calculus to derive equations, but says nothing about how to use them. He is also very quiet and stands in front of the board so you can't see. In summary, you're going to be teaching yourself unless you get a good TA.

Bolland is a very nice person but he's super old and that affects his ability to teach. I could barely understand what he was saying and let me say that I'm super happy I took AP Physics in high school or else I would have failed this class for sure. If you haven't taken AP Physics in high school, drop immediately or go to Lu's lectures. I did that

Bolland was hard to follow. He explained things poorly and would often leave me more confused then when I came into class. I'd taken AP Physics 1 and C Mechanics in HS, but even then I was completely lost on the way he was teaching those materials half the time. If you have him for recitation or lab, good luck since he rarely helps explain things

Bollands lectures are awful and he does a terrible job of explaining the material. Exams are challenging as well. He is a nice man but an awful professor. If you can, change to or simply take PHYS1250 as it covers the same material but you are much more likely to understand the material and pass the exams.

Bolland's lectures are rough. He struggles with technology (like every other 81 y.o.), sometimes screws up demonstrations, and goes off on pointless tangents. Even if you're only understanding half of what he says, it usually makes for an entertaining lecture. He's a nice guy, but if you want to do well, a lot of the learning is on you.

Professor Bolland is very funny and gave out very little homework (1 per week). But, he was not a very good lecturer and messed up a lot. If you have not had a physics course then you are setting yourself up for pain and a low grade. Homework is very hard and there are no quizzes or tests to check your knowledge before the midterm. Glad I dropped.

I struggled a lot in this class. If physics does not come naturally for you, be prepared to spend copious hours outside of class to learn the material. Bolland was a fine lecturer, I think I struggled more because the labs and recitations were not done very well, and I was a freshman with no idea how to study properly.

First midterm: went to class & didnt study a ton: score D+, average was a D+ Second Midterm: went to class & self studied a ton: score C+, average was an F Final: went to class, studied incorrect material (very cumulative exam) score C, average was an F Got an A- overall with an 82%. Bolland is a nice guy; you teach yourself the class.

Had him for Lab / Recitation. Clearly cares about physics and is eager to help you with any questions. Often has issues articulating his thoughts or misunderstands questions but he is very helpful most of the time. We taught him powerpoint when he was our guest lecturer, greatest day of my life.

Lecture has no organization and he basically just seems to ramble the whole time. Usually he just addresses the basic concepts while hw questions and exams go a lot more in depth. Exams were extremely difficult, but he did curve everyone's grade at the end. On the plus side, he is unintentionally hilarious so don't skip lecture.

One on one he can explain everything, as long as he can hear and understand your question. He often misunderstands. Lectures are almost pointless as he rambles on about the subject matter. If you pay attention very hard you can only partially understand what is happening in the class. Labs are a joke. Which is good to buffer your grade.

Biggest plus is that he's incredibly funny. However, there's often miscommunication between him and the TA's on what content to cover, and problem-solving expectations vary wildly between lecture, recitation and lab. This is the only STEM class I've taken where lectures go over my head but sitting down with the book is way more comprehensive.

Expectations of understanding fluctuate wildly between recitation, lab and even during class.  Know that to do remotely well on the exams you must master the material.  That means if you don't understand something you better go to office hours / read the book and figure it out quickly.

Brilliant man, it's obvious he knows and loves physics. That said, I didn't learn much from him. He moves so fast that it's hard to take notes. If you didn't have AP Phys in high school you'll struggle. Labs are a joke, they boost your grade. Recitation problems are very difficult, luckily exams are easier, except the final... dear god that final..

The lectures could be more clear, I believe he's a genius but has a different way of understanding than I do.  The recitation and online problems are very difficult, but the exam questions are less so.  Labs are unhelpful but easy.  many find exams hard but no memorization is necessary so with focus all problems are doable.  course starts slow.

Bolland's lectures were completely useless for the most part. He gets really into his subject, but the lectures are so boring and he will go off on random tangents. The only way to prepare for his tests is reading the book because he throws problems on the exams you will have never seen before. The labs are a joke though which helps your grade.

This class will be really difficult if you did not take AP physics in high school. Dr. Bolland is an adorable old man and obviously loves physics, but he's just not great at teaching it. He skips around a lot and fails to explain how to do problems. Exams are very difficult. Labs are a total joke, you have to show up but there is no mandatory work.

Dr. Bolland is very concise  and always willing to help. His lectures, cool demos, and failure to understand technology newer than 1990 provide for both an entertaining and informative lecture. Going to his lectures and understanding the concept questions really make the difference between As and Cs. The labs for this class are an absolute joke.

confusing when ur taking a big test. Bolland is a very good professor tho! He does some amazing demos in class, very clear & is really passionate about Phys. He wants u to know concepts, so MTs/final consists of about 50% concept Qs. Final exam wasnt too bad except that 40% of it was the newer material (covered after MT2). Overall, great prof!

Nice guy and has a passion for his subject. Sometimes he can contradict/backtrack on what he's said, but that may be because of his age. Honestly, though, it will be your passion for physics that will determine how easy/hard the class is.

You can tell Dr. Bolland still enjoys teaching, and he is available almost all the time in his office if you need help. He's a little quiet, and sometimes confusing while explaining topics, but he also does random, crazy, funny stuff to keep the lecture interesting. If you read the book, go to class, and utilize his office hours, you can do well.

had feh physics 132 with doc bolland.  hes simply too old to teach anymore.  very eccentric and loves what he does, but i didnt learn much from him.  recitation TA became my lifeline.  homeworks and exams written by multiple professors.

This guy is crazy, he is a very intelligent man, but does not relate physics to a college student. He talks way too much theory, and his teaching style is abnormal. Once you get used to it, its not too bad, but I would recommend a different teacher if possible. Overall he is an ok professor

Bolland is a good teacher. He brushes over topics in class so you know what you need to learn but it's necessary to further explore the topics outside of class. He tests are pretty tough but fair. My favorite physics prof thus far.
Physics was always hard for me but Dr. Bolland helped a lot!  He was very accessible and exams and quizzes were off the webassigns.

He's very enthusiastic, but I think old age is getting to his brain. Lectures leave out a Lot and he sometimes forgets things and later comes back to them, or leaves them out completely. 1/4 of the exam was not covered in the lectures.
This guy is crazy and fun to be around. He is quiet though and hard to hear even if you are sitting in the front. He also jumps around a lot during lectures making it kinda hard to follow
hard to follow... lectures are useless

I absolutely loved this guy!! I probably wouldn't have come to lecture if he wasn't so cool. It is so clear he loves his job. His understanding of physics is so strong and  he can explain topics so clearly. I'd taken AP Physics and still didn't quite understand some topics, but when he explained things it made so much sense! Take him!

Lecture was useless. He is very energetic and obviously loves every aspect of physics, but his teaching techniques are questionable. His examples are nice, but other then that its not even worth while to take notes because he switchs topics so much. Basically learned the material in reciation or on my own from the book, so try an get a good TA.

During lecture he seems very excited and acts like he loves physics. BUT, he over-complicates simple stuff and gives too much theory instead of explaining material. He gives the pretense like he wants to help you. But when you come to him, he's mean to you

hilarious guy! he jumped around the room like a cheetah once. i had him for my TA for 111 and thought he was awesome. he's INCREDIBLY smart and always willing to help. he's at Smith every night till midnight reading about physics. he just like Einstein and he invented WEBASSIGN!

He will never teach you application of physics, only theory.  I spent the entire quarter lost with the exception of a single day when we had another professor teaching the class for the day.  His hair is always entertaining though.
Great as a TA at least, helps explain what the lecturer couldn't, all while keeping enthusiasm, which a lot more than I could say for the lecturer

I think this guy was great.  He keeps class interesting, especially for someone not at all interested.  He does alot of example problems to go with the concepts and alot of demonstrations.  If you listen carefully he throws in some unexpected but hilarious jokes.  Exams=hard and online homework.

Wow 111 is a joke.  People actually complain about the workload?  I went to a total of 2 lectures because I found they were not worth the time investment.  People do poorly enough on the tests that they curve 20 or so points.  Way to go OSU students!

Bolland is old yet wise. Hes a great professor and knows what he is talknig about. The one catch is that you must read the book to get the points for the homeworks. If oyu don't get the concepts in lecture, then read the book and all the rest will make sense. Like all science classes physics requires patients and a lot of dedication.
No Comments

This guy is old and wise. He knows what he is talking about but you don't. You have to read the book so you can decode it. He makes alot of mistakes and dosn't prepare for class well. He didn't use Carmen and would post the other professors lecture notes on a Yahoo Group. I didn't like him and warn people against him.
he's pretty animated and fun to watch.  you really need to read the book to prepare for the exams

Bolland was a really interesting guy, and he tried real hard to make the class interesting, but it just didn't work. He could not clearly explain concepts and the averages on the midterms were pretty low. He was fair with his curvature of the class however.
Bolland knows his stuff but has a hard time conveying it to someone who doesnt know physics. makes his tests and quizzes mostly conceptual and most of those questions are very random and difficult.

I agree with everyone else.  my TA's were the lifeline to understand physics.  I think it's great that Bolland really loves teaching physics, but he really sucks at teaching.  Bolland is for anyone who already understands physics and can share his enthusiasm.

Not a bad lecture, but very boring.  He's very enthusiastic during lecture...seems kinda out there.  He curves his class a lot, our midterms had a 23% curve.  Most of his questions are really conceptual so beware.  If you have the choice however, take Dotty.

I can't believe i took two classes under him, but unfortunately due to my major scheduling, 131 & 132 are PRE-REQs, so I had to rush to get them done. Funny fellow, but makes you wish he was nicer in terms of grading and explaining homework. Get in touch with your TAs! They will be your lifelines...
No Comments

Dr. B. gives a decent class in physics and gets excited about the topic. However, get to know your TA, mine unfortunately was Dr. B. Hard to get additional viewpoints on material and he doesn't like to help much. Will make you feel dumb if you are unable to grasp time dilation. Good luck.

One of the absolute best professors in my three years at OSU.  He puts so much effort into his course that it is difficult to find a single fault with it; I am genuinely puzzled by the hostility that some students have for him.
Can someone say "old Bill Nye??" A lot of things were ok in his class, but when I came to him for help, he seemed to be unattached, and made me feel a lttle bit like a burden on him.
Tests are hard and too long for the time provided.Like proving theories instead of explaining or giving examples.Very helpful though.Should come to the office hours, if you need help.
I thought Professor Boland was an unclear lecturer and pretty much was forced to depend on my TA.
Loves physics!  Dr. B is very approachable, very excitable, and very much committed to helping students understand the material.  I loved his lectures.  "That dog won't hunt!"
Very hard, intimidating. Has hot jokes.
Lots of office hours, if you have alot of question, he is willing to answer all of them. Quiz and exams are all based on homework problems.

He looks like a crazy scientist and it's so appropriate becuase he absolutely loves his job.  He gets kind of excited about physics, which makes the class interesting.  His 109 section had no formal tests; the grade was based soley on quizzes.
He does have the crazy scientist look, but lectures tend to be fun because of the demos.
No Comments

Very amusing! Teaches a comprehension-based approach to physics with demonstrations in stead of relying upon formulae memorization. WRITES TESTS THAT ARE TOO LONG FOR THE ALOTTED TIME, though, in my professional opinion (as a student who rarely finishes).
Looks like a crazy physicist who can do some crazy stuff...Lectures very helpful, class demos ammusing, very dedicated to his job.
No Comments
Very clear and intellegent-- but study hard for the tests!
No Comments
looks crazy, does crazy equations, but you learn a ton from him
absolutely loves his job.  very interested in what he teaches.
No Comments
Boring.  Over-complicating.
No Comments
No Comments
I was meh towards this class until the final I just took. I have never been done dirty like that in physics before. Quizzes were unnecessarily hard given we just learned the material 4 seconds ago
Great lecturer. Bogged down by the physics department board.

Very nice but I feel like I never learned anything in his lectures. During exams the Qs the other professors made were much harder and stuff he never went over so I suggest you read the book too or watch some youtube videos. Study his practice problems (from lecture) and the quiz questions and you can do well!

I really wish I was better at math because this class wouldn't have been that bad. Dr. H's lectures might be a bit boring, but he leaves room for students to ask questions and will do his best to answer those questions as well as he can. The lecture slides are kinda messy though and can be difficult to understand. Overall though, he's a good prof!

I am not someone who excels in math based courses but, this class has been tremendous in giving the materials required to succeed no matter the skill level. Prof. Humanic is a very sweet man who provided the materials and patience that I personally am grateful for in a class that is typically seen as a difficult class.

Dr. Humanic is a very nice grandpa-type professor, very kind and always willing to help, so do not hesitate to ask questions. Also, definitely utilize your TA. Physics is hard, so you really have to put in the work, attend lectures, read the textbook, do problems. Exams are concept and math based, make sure to understand the material.
Dr. Humanic made learning physics possible. With thought out lectures and demos, he really cares deeply to be sure his students understand the material forwards and backwards. I definitely recommend.

Prof. Humanic is like your cute grandpa; he is super nice and obviously caring. His lectures are clear and concise. Although physics is a difficult subject, he understands that it is a prerequisite for a lot of classes. He takes questions in lecture and answers them well. The online homework and weekly quizzes are annoying but not impossible.
One of the best profs I have had, he was clear and concise. Great lectures and slides are posted online. Weekly quizzes, but only 5 questions on each one.

Very clear with material. Weekly quizzes were all very reasonable. Exams were all straightforward, Dr. Humanic says the difficulty of the exams are similar to the quizzes, and I would agree. Lectures are solid, as he does in-class demonstrations to keep things interesting.

Dr. Humanic has been really great. It is clear he really knows the material and he only covers necessary information, and does so very clearly. His powerpoints are really helpful to go back and look at, and if you are unable to attend lecture, the powerpoints are so detailed it isn't a huge deal (he goes a bit more in depth in class though).

Dr. Humanic was extremely straightforward. His quizzes and exams are based on his lecture notes and never threw any curve balls. The class material itself was not super interesting, but Dr. Humanic did multiple demos to keep us awake during class. He is such a kind and caring professor and really wanted his students to do well.
quizzes and midterms are very fair.  would've gotten an A if research and work didn't keep me from studying.  very kind man who has the interest of students at heart, reminds me of grandpa.

Awesome prof! His quizzes were pieces of cake, nearly identical problems to the notes. Exams are fair and he tells you what the written problems will be. Lecture wasn't always necessary because its just learning the equations, which you are given anyways.

Dr. Humanic has very clear lectures and he explains the course material very well! He really cares about his students and is willing to help. I'm usually bad at physics but thanks to his clear teaching style and good explanations I was able to do well! Very glad I had him as my professor for this class!

Probably one of the best 1200 level lecturers. Exams are very similar to homework and quiz material. He puts the slides from every lecture online, so if you're decent at physics you might not ever have to go to lecture. Quiz and online homework every week. Labs are an easy A. Just do well on homework and quizzes and you're golden
Lectures very clear, easy to understand, lots of examples and demonstrations
He is a great professor. Super nice and funny. Very clear with what will be on test and quizzes. He gives great lectures. So far one of my favorite professors. Highly encourage others to take him.
Great professor. Told what was to be expected on exams and gave good examples in class. Quizzes were similar to examples done in class.

Humanic was a great professor who was genuinely interested in the topic. His tests were very straightforward and were easier versions of the homework. He does lots of entertaining demos in class and really seems to care about the students. He even tells you the free response questions that will be on the exams. Just go to class!

Best professor for Physics 1200. His quizzes and tests were straightforward. I did not study much and ended with an A. His final was the test and quizzes. His lecture is boring but he has cool demos and makes his slideshows easy to follow. He could have made physics difficult be he didnt. I would take him!!!

Not the easiest class. Maybe things have changed from before. I'm still on track thanks to the curve. I'd be grateful if the quizzes were curved too. Even 1 point would help. I would suggest you take Dr. Yang.
Good/nice prof. Best physics teacher I've had. Quizzes are easy but studying is NECESSARY for exams which are mult. choice + 2 show work. He tells you what the show work problems are.
Good Professor. He does a lot of mathematical and conceptual examples in lecture. Know how to do the homework problems and you will have no problem with this class.
Very easy. Know how to do problems in the homework and you're set. Most problems based on plugging values into an equation.
easy to follow, has powerpoints but still does examples on the board for clarity
Cool dude.
Physics 1250 was a pretty hard class for me but Carter Swift as a TA made it much better. He always was good at explaining things and was pretty chill in the lab.

Prof Lu. taught 1st year-graduate quantum mechanics. I thought I understood quantum mechanics before but I was wrong and Lu showed us the correct way of understanding physics. My life as a physicist will never be the same. I enjoyed his selection of advanced topics and most of the other graduate students agree. I hope he always teaches this class.

Professor Lu is the best Physics Professor I have had. He is a very good teacher and lecturer and explains concepts very well. He does practice problems in class that help you understand the topic. His review questions he provides are representative of what is on the exam. If you miss lectures you will not do good. Lectures are very important.

I initially went to Bolland's lectures and I found about Lu's lectures and thankfully, I had no time conflict. Professor Lu is the reason I got the grade which is shown above or else I would have failed if I stayed with Bolland. He was funny, explained things very well, and overall a good professor. Be ready to go to every lecture and don't skip.

Dr. Lu was a great professor. At the beginning of the semester, he was all over the place and was not communicating effectively. It was his first time teaching 1201, but he improved quickly. He even took half of a class period to have the students give him feedback when he noticed that we were struggling. He is a good professor and I recommend him.

Professor Lu was an OK prof at best. He often rushed through material and was not clear and concise when he explained it. There is somewhat of a language barrier so I think that may have been what made it hard. Try to avoid taking this prof. Quizzes were much harder than other sections from what I heard. Good curves and shift points though.

He's hilarious and you can tell he wants students to understand the material. He will pause and ask if anyone has questions. However, sometimes he doesn't explain things in ways students can easily understand because he's extremely smart. Labs are giveaway points. Saving grace: many questions on exams were the exact ones he did in lecture.

Lu is ridiculously smart and really cares abut how much everyone understands things. Come to lecture with questions and don't be afraid to volunteer for demos. Go to office hours, he is super happy to help anyone understand anything they may be having trouble with. Pay attention in lecture. Problems he says are important are probably on the test

I LOVE YUAN-MING LU. In all seriousness I think Lu is a super great teacher though his lectures were pretty high level. Make sure you do your prep work and you will be okay. He also really cares about his students, that is obvious, and is really helpful with questions at office hours.

Dr. Lu is a funny guy and a great professor. It is obvious in class that he has a real passion for physics and is extremely knowledgeable about it. Lectures are extremely dense and he spends a lot of time on derivation. He teaches like students are PhD candidates but still a good class.

Dr. Lu is a really good lecturer. He explains complicated topics in a way that is easy for to understand. His lectures are also interesting and fun with all his demonstrations. He is also really funny and always makes sure everyone in the class understands what he is teaching.

Dr. Lu is the only reason I passed this class. If i find out he is not given total control of this course next year I will be furious because he is one of the best teachers I've ever had. Although the course material is difficult he makes lectures really entertaining and slows down a lot to help people understand.

He was the new guy for physics 1260. At first, he wasnt there the first week so we had Bolland teaching. I basically fell asleep in class. Then Lu came, he talks quick, but was energetic and wanted to connect with the class. He wanted all of us to learn. And he is unintentionally funny with his demonstrations and a great guy altogether.

Dr. Lu was by far the best professor during my freshman year. The material was very tough and taught at a fast pace, but his lectures were amazing. He went over the material in an easy-to-understand way and did many practice problems to cement our knowledge. He was readily available outside of class for help and genuinely cared about our success.

Roland Kawakami, the Physics 1250 maestro at Ohio State, is a gem. His humor lights up Smith Labs, where he dazzles with spot-on demonstrations. He weaves content seamlessly, offering stellar study guides and unwavering support. Inspiring, caring, and funny, Kawakami makes physics "totally legit."

I took 1250H and 1251H. Dr. Kawakami is the absolute GOAT of the physics department. Lectures were great, and I liked how he showed the derivations for all the equations we used. The class and content was formatted well. He's also a really funny and caring guy. Great professor, great physicist, great guy. This class is totally legit!
Literally the GOAT, greatest of all time, he is the best. I feel like Feynman now. This guy is totally legit.
Lecture heavy class, pay attention and you should be good. A lot of 1250 was review from high school AP, which always helps. Ask questions if you have a problem, he will be very happy to answer.

Took the 1250H course not listed here as an engineering college requirement. Very good at covering the content, which helped since I'm not interested in Physics. Reached out to me and was willing to make accommodations when I struggled. Just be wary that exams/quizzes combine for 60% of your grade in this class, although homework is very light!

His lectures aren't the best but he does cover the course materials you need to know for labs and exams. His tests are easy if you successfully complete the homework and labs. He went through examples during class and used TopHat to see how students are performing. You may find his lectures dull but they are definitely helpful for hw & exams!

Physics 1250 is a horribly structured and intensive class. But if there's one professor you want to have to get you through it, it's Kawakami. His funny lectures and extensive knowledge of physics can help you master the subject if you commit to it. He explicitly lays out what midterms will be over and offers so many resources. Overall a great guy.

Dr. Kawakami was a solid prof. He did a good job explaining the content and was always open to sugesstion and feedback regarding the class, which I appreciated. The homework is brutal and there's a lot of content that has to be covered, but Kawakami definetly did the best possible job conveying the information to students in the given time.

Tries his best to make the lecture material understandable but with the amount of the material covered in so little time its difficult. He does a great job of communicating what topics will be covered on the exams and tries to give as much materials as possible to help you prepare.

Roland is the best. So the thing about physics at OSU is that it's ass. Roland can't control anything but the exams and his lectures. The homework is all standardized throughout the department, and the homework sucks. But he makes it clear what he puts on the exams and has great lectures, holds reviews sessions before exams which are very helpful.
I skipped my other physics teacher's lectures to come to Roland. He is a great teacher with a ton of demos that really showed how much he cares about his students. TMNT forever.
Professor was awesome. Cared about teaching. GOAT of the physics department at OSU. TMNT.

The guy can't teach. He tends to work through a loop several times in a lecture that goes "begin explaining a concept, go on a tangent, remember that time's limited, rush through the content so students have no chance of following along". He's very nice and loves the material but that's of no value to a student that needs to understand his lecture.
Nice guy, but an awful teacher. Can never get ahold of him because he never responds to his emails. I'm sorry, but he is the worst teacher I have ever experienced.
he does not explain anything he does; use organic chemistry teacher online if you actually want to learn

Professor Kawakami brings a refreshing enthusiasm to class each day, always trying to make the mood lighter with jokes. He teaches well and is helpful in office hours. The course in general is difficult though and if you don't put in the work you won't pass.

I loved Dr. Kawakami. He was very helpful in office hours and he's funny during lecture. Physics 1250 is honestly hard in general but with him he didn't make it that bad. The only issue I have with him is his tendency to focus on derivations instead of the actual concepts. But if you ask for help, he will help and explain to you.

I loved having Professor Kawakami this semester. He was an amazing lecturer, was incredibly accessible outside of lectures, and was always open to questions. The examples in class were either hit or miss as to how helpful they were. The lectures tended to shy away from physics and focused on derivations, though.

Physics 1250 was a pain in the butt. Dr. Kawakami is a funny guy but not the best teacher. I was pretty much self taught for this class. Get ready to fail exams because this class is that hard. Make sure you stay in top of the Pre-labs and Webassigns cause they will bite you in the butt if you forget about them.

I almost feel bad for him because he seems like a great person who has an awesome sense of humor and is very knowledgeable in what he does. However, he focuses too much on derivations and does not explain problems very well. 1250 is just super hard in general but I feel like he did the best he could given the COVID circumstances. Nice guy.

Kawakami is very clearly passionate about teaching. He enjoys students and helping them. However, his lectures sometimes focus too much on derivations of formulas and concepts rather than the relevant material itself. The derivations never helped me. His lectures will help you but you cannot rely on them. Do your homework in the tutoring room.

Physics 1250 sucks all I have to say but out of all the professors, I would recommend Kawakami. He gives the easiest exams out of all the physics professors and makes lectures not horrible, however, he has a tendency to ramble.
Tests were managable and he didn't try to make trick questions. His test problems were similar to lecture examples. He can be unclear at times, but reading the textbook should help.

Lectures often focused too much on proofs than application, which was a bummer. All class notes are uploaded online. Provided practice tests and review sessions. Office hours were great for homework help. Very nice and funny guy. His tests are mostly straightforward, and the average is shifted if too low. Use the resources he gives you. He's decent

He knows a lot, mostly a research-based professor. Not good at teaching "academically" for undergrad students. Spends too much time explaining unnecessary stuff. If you wanna pass, you have to teach yourself or get help from the TA. Lectures are boring and uninteresting. I wish I didn't have to take him.

Dr. Kawakami is a fair professor. While his exams are getting harder, they are very reasonable and as long as you come to class and do the homework you are going to be just fine. His exams and quizzes are straightforward.

He would refuse to give examples during his lectures and only taught theory and then expected you to be able to complete problems on assignments. Knew someone in the class whose mom died that semester and he targeted him for not being able to come to all classes and would call him out during lectures. Because of this he got fired from OSU I think

Dr. Chowdhurry has trouble articulating course content despite his enthusiasm about the subject matter. He tries to make jokes and be light hearted but it doesn't make up for the poor instruction. Additionally, he seems very nice on the surface but can be harsh and is not understanding when extenuating circumstances arise.

Not a great professor. Half the class dropped course within 2 weeks. Has problem articulating ideas. The course materials were not presented to be very interesting. A nice person. You can approach him about any missed homework or assignment. Likes to make lame jokes.

This instructor genuinely cared about supporting students in written feedback and verbally during office hours and exam study sessions. The instructor was accessible outside of class and inspired me to study hard even when the course material became very difficult. I really appreciated the effort they put into class prep and good homework feedback.

I had him for PHYS 5400 and PHYS 5500H, and it was incredible. Before each midterm his help was immense providing excellent practice and breaking down the concepts in a very clear and digestible way. Aside from that he fostered a very good learning environment and genuinely cares about each and every one of his students.

I have had him for Physics 5400, 5500, and 5600. Gives very clear explanations with interesting and thought-provoking examples. One of the best graduate teaching assistants I have had for my physics classes.
Would take it again.

He's very passionate about the subject, yet he still only teaches what we need to know and in a way we will remember. Physics 1250 at OSU is naturally a tough subject, but he does his best to make it easier and more enjoyable. My favorite teacher from OSU by far.

Professor cares about teaching very much, however, he does not go very in depth in lectures and most of the time it is hard to even understand what he is talking about. He tried to help, but the class is formatted so poorly that he couldn't make up for it.

Honestly if you take 1250 don't go to lectures. Watch Organic chemistry tutor and read his slides online. His multiple-choice questions are exactly like the exam and at times are the EXACT same as the exam. Good teacher just goes fast and in person you may fall behind.

Wonderful guy but cursed to teach the dreadful Physics 1250 course. I love his personality, enthusiasm, and humor but this class is hell if you aren't a fan of spending multiple hours a day studying. For what it's worth, one of my friends joined one of my exam-prep lectures with him and said he was far better at teaching than their professor.
Good

Nice. Answers questions via email. Most of the problems with physics 1250 at OSU stem from the department as a whole. They are falling apart. Lei Bao teaches by putting practice problems on slides. I learned a lot of equations but I dont really know how physics works at the end of the sem. Not Baos fault entirely. Just a lot of content.

The way Lei Bao teaches won't work for everyone, but I think he did a good job. He is very upfront with what will and won't be tested on quizzes and exams and the questions on them are very similar to questions done in lecture. The final was not written by him, so it was much harder than the first two midterms.
Hard to understand, end up learning content elsewhere is required to do well on exams
All I have to say is Lei Bao is the GOAT. If you get to stand in his presence you will not be disappointed. It's slightly difficult to get into the swing of things at first, but it gets much better.

An excellent professor! Works hard to make sure students understand the concepts well, lectures are informative and engaging, and its obvious he really cares about both the students and the subject. Also very kind and understanding if theres a problem.
Dr. Bao is by far the most amazing lecturer to ever attend The Ohio State University. I felt lucky to even stand in his presence (through Zoom).
Great professor, the best!!!
Dr. Bao is very good at his job! He is an amazing teacher that's why I go to his office hours all the time. Those office hours really helped me a lot!

Many creative ways in teaching the material where participation during lectures feels more engaging and interactive, making it easier to understand and get in contact with the material. Great professor!
Dr. Bao is a really good physics professor. He is a nice guy and give me many advices on my work. Overall a great instructor.

Professor Bao is one of the best professors Ive ever had at OSU. He is very caring and wants the students to learn the material. He is also exceptional at explaining abstract concepts and turning them into easier things to understand. I would recommend him for sure!
pretty good

I've come to the realization that his man's style is not for everyone. He used lots of demonstrations and he used a tophat-like class participation thing. These really helped me learn the material, and it made his lectures fun too, but some people find him hard to understand I guess. I really loved his class though. Also easy quizzes and exams.

He's not the easiest to understand and very awkward during lectures. Not very clear with the information he conveys. However, he posted all of his lecture notes online and had easy exams compared to the other professors. If you have prior experience with AP Physics 1 and 2, he might be a good option because the tests are easy. Otherwise don't.

Had him last semester and he was awful. He made this class was extremely stressful and I had no idea what was going on half the time because he was such a bad lecturer. He was terrible at explaining everything; I'd sit in lecture and just think "What is he even talking about?" most of the time. I had to sit in on other prof's lectures to learn.
It looks like many of the older reviews, all posted on may 13th are fake. Bao is in no way a good professor, but gives the easiest exams. Avoid.

Bao is terrible at explaining things and he speeds through 50 slides a class. Quizzes/mid terms are very unclear about what they are over. Other physics lecturers give study guides or practice midterms, but we were given nothing at all to study. Other lecturers had much easier quizzes, but bao gave easier finals.

The exams are comparably easier than other tests that professors make for Physics 1250. However, Professor Bao does not lecture the material clearly. He tends to teach by making students attempt to understand the material first via clicker-style activities and flies through all the lecture slides. It isn't clear what to take notes on either.

One of the worst professors I have ever had. Attending lecture is barely helpful as he zooms through the slides with very little explanation and tells you to look at them after class (which isn't helpful because none of it makes sense on your own). Homework doesn't relate to the quizzes at all. I have no idea what's going on half the time.
Amazing teacher :)
This man is a legend and everyone should have him

Great Professor. Lectures are not mandatory but very useful. Exams are easier than other professor's in the same class. I suggest going to reviews as he covers everything you'll need to know for the midterms and finals. Other than that make sure you do all the online homework and you should be fine in this class.

He tries to avoid just lecturing people by using proven methods of in class participation that involve the students in the class and doesn't single out anyone. He keeps a comedic mood and is well liked by everyone that I have talked to. He makes the tests based on the concepts rather than plug and chug equations. Easy tests and quizzes.

Take this professor and you will receive at least a B- in Physics 2. He thinks he is some kind of distinguished educator.  Honestly He is so confusing  and doesnt really now how to teach at all. In the end he will give easy tests so people pass.

Hands down the best professor I have ever had. After this course I fell in love with physics. I used to think taking physics was a burden, but now I enjoy learning physics. I also met his son Albert Bao who is a great guy and we eat lunch together. Today I am famous physicist and discovered gravitational waves because of the help of this great man.
Great teacher really covers content, kinda hard though
3 thanks for my current job

Lei Bao is not only a professor, but a inspirational friend. He is so genuinely nice and respectful. His son has similar traits. Lei Bao has taught his son well. Lei Bao has always been there for me. He is truly a wonderful man.
My favorite professor or ALL TIME.
I love Lei Bao he is an amazing teacher. If I had the chance to take this course again, I would take this course again! Thank You Lei Bao for being such a great person such a great professor!
Enthusiastic but not very helpful with material. Learn on your own.
Very good teacher.
Lectures are good but go to office hours, he will help you. Review the slide questions, they will be in quizzes. If you do the homework, you will be fine.

Rarely answered questions in person, only on his website. Very limited and inconvenient office hours. He gave next to no review material for exams and if asked, would tell you to study your HW to prepare. Never responded to a single email. He went out of his way to be unhelpful. You will have to teach yourself.

Lectures are next to useless, since most of the material covered in class was never on exams or quizzes or beyond the scope of the class. No review material for exams, and he will only say to look over the homework and past quizzes. Exams are easier than others though, namely Porter.

Worst professor I've had in my 3 years at OSU. Wastes class time with demonstrations, clicker questions on material you haven't covered, and examples that he says you don't need to know for the test. Constantly contradicts himself when asked what material is on a test. Whenever asked a question, tells you to study the homework questions.
His Q&A site is very useful.A funny guy. Maybe try cover less content.

He pulls his quiz and test questions from the class slides, which is nice, but he's not very good at explaining how to do the problems in class. I had to go over the slides with my TA, watch Yale's online lectures, and sit in Dr. Schumacher's lectures to pull my grade up. Don't take this class with him, but use his Q&A site: LeiAcademy. Google it.

A good and funny professor. Homework is harder than quizzes and tests. Don't need textbook at all. Everything you need for midterms and quizzes comes from his lecture slides and he reuses a lot of multiple choice questions from his slides on the tests.Go to the lectures, he usually hints what problems will be on the midterms and quizzes.

I went to four lectures total during the semester and wish I hadn't wasted my time with that many. He was very hard to understand and always laughed at his own jokes that weren't funny. Terrible teacher but not that hard.
He is a funny guy and his exams/quizzes are much easier than homework, if you could fully understand the homework. An easy A.

Possibly the worst professor I have had in 3 years of college. He treated the class like we were an experiment for his teaching strategies, none of which were actually effective. Half the teaching is through clicker questions and the other half is him showing how to derive and integrate equations, but not how to apply them. Do not take  this class.

He was either conducting a psychological experiment or testing the waters for a career as a comedian, both of which fell flat. I quite frankly have no idea what I spent this whole semester "learning," and instead focused on memorizing the example questions--which is the only way to save your GPA. Do yourself a favour and skip this one.

If you have any hope of learning anything don't take his class. The last time I had physics was over 13 years ago and I am totally lost and he doesn't explain things very well at all. Take it at CSCC if you want, every physics professor at OSU is super hard or can't teach.

The lectures are boring and not very clear.  The class is all about the process of using equations absolutely nothing about the intellect behind the ideas.  Unless you like watching a guy solve a few math problems every lecture, dont take this class.  I asked one question all semester and he told me to look it up.

I learned the class from my graduate TA. The stuff he teaches in lecture 100% clicker questions. Very unclear in his explanations. He is funny and a very nice person, but not helpful at all. The reason I am doing well in the class is primarily by teaching myself and emailing my TA, who is a doctoral student. DO NOT SCHEDULE LEI BAO if you can.

Teaches primarily methodology with little to no emphasis on conceptual understanding. The whole class is clicker questions, and he only answers them for the class about 70% of the time even if there is a large split in percentage per response. A graduate TA taught one lecture and left to a spontaneous standing ovation.
enthusiastic , creative.

He does have a strong accent but I got over it pretty quick. The quizzes are usually material gone over in lecture, which tend to be somewhat interesting as he's often making goofy comments and odd experiments which seem to cause him bodily harm. He teaches very conceptually, but is sometimes unclear and skips steps to certain problems.

You really have to rely on your T.A. for this class. Homework and pre-labs due every week online. Weekly quizzes but you get to drop your 2 lowest ones. Make sure you go to the labs. You get more credit just by showing up to labs than for homework assignments. The midterms are hard, but it's still passible with a good curve.

Yeah, he has an accent, but it's not hard to understand. The class was hard, but so is Physics...so that only makes sense. He emphasizes conceptual understanding, so that's good. Reading the book and doing homework is a must, but it pays off. The class was appropriately hard and he taught well, I believe.
It was hard to understand his accent.  The quizzes and homework aren't that hard but the midterms and final are.

Pretty easy exams compared to other 131 classes. Not the best instructor, spoke pretty poor english, examples were unclear in class, and had trouble with the technology. Worked harder to make students laugh than to actually teach physics.

goofball, did all work and examples in variables which sucked at first but helps you in the long run. tries to be funny too much, but on occasion he delivers b/c he'll cause himself bodily harm for your enjoyment. overall not good, not bad

not too great of a professor. didn't really try to teach, which he wasn't good at, and tryed to make us laugh, which he wasn't good at. the only reason i was interested in going to class was to see how ridiculously stupid it was going to be. i probably could've taught the class better than he could
Hated the class because he cared way more about making the students laugh than teaching us how to do stuff. Do not take this professor.
No Comments

This class is standardized so I'm not sure that having a different professor would change things much. I did not find his lectures helpful at all so make sure you understand the work in recitation. Nice guy, but tends to explain the algebra instead of the actual concepts.

Dr. Heckler is a super kind and genuine professor. He makes his lectures engaging but are not completely necessary to attend. Midterms and finals are kind of cutthroat as you get no partial credit. Each question on the midterm is worth about 8%. Physics is time-consuming but Dr. Heckler is a wonderful prof to have. The physics department sucks tho

I don't know if it was the department or him but this is probably one of the worst professors I have ever had. Most of the time I am looking up videos outside of class and teaching myself. He spends way too much time on demonstrations and not on actually teaching the material. He seems nice but unless you want to teach yourself physics don't bother

Physics is hard of course, but Dr. Heckler really cares! DO NOT SKIP TOO MANY LECTURES, unless you are very good at physics, it will be hard to catch up on missed lectures alone. Group recitations, a lot of completion assignments, and weekly quizzes. It isn't unbearable though, just go to office hours!

Prof. Heckler is an excellent physics teacher. With the class being standardized across all 1200 teachers he makes it so enjoyable and fun. His quizzes are straightforward and makes it easy to do well in the class. Prepares you extremely well for the exams. Highly recomend!
Heckler is  one of the best professors I've had in college. He is very helpful, always willing to answer any questions I had. I learned a great deal from him.
Dr. Heckler is highly intelligent, and can really relate to students. Labs are helpful, but not difficult, and homework is not too miserable.
Rambled during class and answered abstract questions that he should have said he would answer during office hours.

Professor Heckler is a great teacher! His research is in how people learn physics so he is very in tune with the difficulties that students have with the classes he teaches. He is very willing to help, not just during office hours but any time. I had him for both 131 and 133 and he was great for both classes!
He was a good professor. The course in general was hard, but he was very willing to help. I was in his office hours every week. Very upbeat personality.

He is a tough professor but he is willing to help you! He may expect you to learn more then you want to at times but he is helping you to think like you need to in order to pass the next class in physics! people need to stop bashing him and just work hard.
Not a bad teacher. He explained everything just about as clearly as someone teaching E&M can.
Amazing Teacher, very helpful

I think it would be a little unfair to completely bash on Dr. Heckler.  He is a great professor, but quantum physics and special relativity are very abstract sciences. He explained everything the best any physicist can at this point and for some people that just isn't enough. The biggest thing is to make use of your TA's during recitation.
Heckler was quite useless overall; he didn't teach much during lectures and tended to ramble on about things that were not part of the class.  I stopped going to lecture and my grade didn't suffer.

Good professor.  Make use of your TA's for questions on the webwork and homework assignments, but asking Heckler before class will definitely help out.  If you dont understand something, ask, and he tends to be able to clarify things.  His demos are cool.

He had a fairly exciting, but ultimately useless lecture.  I didn't even go to lecture the last 3 weeks. I actually enjoyed the material by itself though, so I would have enjoyed it more if he actually taught more.  I guess he's pretty good 1 on 1, but I never went to his office hours - I liked my TA much better for that.

Good prof. doesn't spend a lot of extra time on problems, goes through things pretty quick but does does well explaining why things are like they are in reality, doesn't do as well explaining how it works on paper. definitely keeps you interested and makes it fun.
Not the world's greatest prof, but good for a laugh at times.  He needs to spend more time actually teaching content and how to approach problems.
Awesome teacher.  I was not scheduled for his lecture, but I went to his lecture because he is such a great professor!

AHeckler = Amazing.  He made me want to go to Phsics Leccture... which is a feat, if you know me.  He kept things fun, and was always open to, and encouraged, questions during class.  He seemed to love helping students work things out, and was great one-on-one in his office hours.  I'd have him again if I could.
Very helpful if you go to his office hours, keeps the class interesting.
Funny guy.  Good prof.  The material wasn't too exciting but hey that's phsyics.
Very good teacher and helpful when it comes to explainations.  Very clear and concise.
Never had a boring lecture
No Comments
Decent teacher, but he's on sabatical
Seems very interested in teaching.  He's having fun, which makes his students have a good time... even though the material wasn't very exciting.
Heckler spends way too much time messing with his experiments and not enough time showing students how to approach problems.  All he is good for is a laugh.

This class is undeniably the hardest physics course you will take at Ohio State. Chris absolutely does the best he can to teach the material, and he does it well, but I cannot deny the fact that you might be completely lost in this class, so be prepared for that. Great guy, wants to make sure you understand everything, so ask questions!

Professor Hirata actually made Physics 1251 bearable, he is funny and extremely smart, and he always tries to give examples of concepts and show how each equation is derived. The class itself was awful, would not recommend, but if you have to take 1251, definitely try to get Hirata. He is amazing!

Dr Hirata is a brilliant guy, but sometimes that can create a barrier between him and his students. His lectures are very deep but you can get lost very easily if you aren't paying full attention. You might miss one detail during a lecture and the rest just doesn't make any sense. His exams are incredibly difficult, but a 75 ended up being an A.

Only received an A+ because of the 20% coronavirus curve. This class is so incredibly hard. Hirata is a very smart and nice guy. I can tell he wants to help his students. His knowledge however is just so above my basic understanding so it was hard to get on his level in lectures and actually understand what was going on. He tried though, he was new

This is the hardest class I've ever taken. Both the final and first midterm had failing averages. That said, the curve is great. 75% and above was an A. If you do all your work and study the curve will get you a decent grade. He cares about his students and uploads all his notes online. You mine as well take a class with OSU's resident genius.

He is a caring guy, and available outside of class but his exams are so hard and the quizzes too. He gives practices exams and quizzes they are hard but doable. When it comes to exams my friend hold you belt tight cause its harrrd. the average of the first exam was 44 and the highest was 80. the final was the same

This was by far the most difficult class I've taken during college, and I don't see anything topping it any time soon. Dr. Hirata made it very hard. Don't get me wrong he is a super caring and genuine guy, but his lectures were basically just complex derivations of difficult calculus equations. 1st exam avg was a 44% and it didn't get much better

Take my advice with a grain of salt, I am an electrical engineer with a physics minor. Class was well taught, homework was challenging but useful and Jay keeps the lectures funny, interesting and practical. Exams were hard, but he did curve. Jay was the only physics prof I had during my minor that was both a genius and knew how to teach well.

One of the best professors you can get from physics deprtment!! He knows a lot about physics and follows his own pedagogy inspired by Feynman. He enjoys talking with you if you are prepared and bring some questions. Go to talk with him! You will learn a lot and be amazed by his mind.
I can't praise his teaching enough. His lectures are really well done and the homework isn't too miserable. Take if you can: he's well worth your time

Dr. Jayaprakash is the perfect professor. He is brilliant, helpful, and has an unfathomably deep knowledge of physics. He teaches theory, intuition, applications, maths, and history with informative, helpful and very entertaining lectures. I wish he taught (nearly) every class during my college career because I would have learned so much more.

He was one of the best Physics professor in OSU...He tried to make you understand the concept of Quantum Mechanic perfectly. He always revised the materials covered in the class. His grading was fair too. However, because the Quantum Mechanic course was too hard to learn, I didn't get what I aimed for the grade...Quite rare to see him outside the c

In a word - awesome. His is one of the few classes that makes an hour long commute worth it. Definitely take any class he offers. Most of the prof's here have been good, but he is (so far) the one to beat as far as what a professor should be.

One of the best professors at this university. Great explanations, extremely helpful, and funny. He has great stories to add depth to what you are learning and the intangibles of a great teacher. Took quantum from him which is a difficult subject to teach and feel that I understand this batter than any other subject I have taken. Take his classes.

Class is super hard, so I don't blame him for being useless, but he is. In-class work is extremely different than homework and tests. Your biggest resource is the tutoring room. The way he sets up Carmen is insane. Show up to lectures, he doesn't know how to use zoom well.

He's a great guy but 1250 is just extremely difficult. Shoves 1 year's worth of AP Physics C material into essentially 4 months. We spend 3 weeks on Kinematics at first and then breeze through fluid dynamics and special relativity in 55 minutes. Highly recommend downloading the solutions manual and doing lots of problems on your own. Start HW EARLY

DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS. He often made mistakes in class and would get confused. I learned nothing from his class and had to learn everything from YouTube. Exams are super hard and do not compare to anything learned in class.

Honestly, I missed about 75% of his lectures. However, he seemed to be a good professor, but he tended to talk a lot, making it easy to lose focus. Although he records his lectures, the quality has been inconsistent.
Great professor but makes mistakes frequently when working out problems. Does a great job of explaining concepts and seems to care about his students.

As is the case with many physics professors, he was okay in lectures but admitted the structure of the course is not flexible. This was my first physics class, so I read the textbook and showed up to lectures with pre-made notes and that helped a lot. I thought the exams were easier than the quizzes, but make sure you are prepared.

He cared about his students, but didn't answer questions clearly. Nothing in lecture seemed to correlate to the homework so I ended up using notes from a different professor and I was able to figure it out. Really easy to listen to, but its better to learn the topic before lecture so you can decipher what he's trying to teach and not get confused.

Note: this was my first Physics class so I don't know how good he is comparatively. Overall, meh. I never attended lecture, just self-studied from the textbook and got an A, but when I dropped in, he was giving good feedback to students when they had questions. The grading is bad though, like missing just a few questions on midterms costs you.

Great lecturer, and explains concepts in ways that students understand well. However, he often makes mistakes in his notes that usually leave students a bit confused. Other than that I do wish there were actual recitations instead of just "quiz periods" which is what the "recitations" are. I recommend his office hours, they're very helpful.

Many of the people reviewing here are not reviewing this professor for Physics 1250 - so listen closely. I can't speak for other courses, but Zeke teaches 1250 in a way that makes it so much more understandable than I ever could've imagined. Pay attention in his lectures and you will likely enjoy them. He knows how to bring humor into it.

This class was extremely not structured well at all. Many students who had Zeke as their lecturer went to other professors review sessions and office hours to get help. He doesn't teach the material well at all and you have to learn everything outside of class. Also, never ask him a question because you will be more confused than before.

This class is organized horribly. There is no recitation time to ask questions and it's a quiz period. They only teach the basics, while throwing problems that are meant for students who have been taking physics for many years and have understandings of many different concepts, including calculus (which is not a pre-req for the class). I hate this.

He knows how to explain the basics and he helps us understand the basics. However, when it comes to the midterms, quizzes, hand in work, and the online weekly work, the basics get you almost nowhere, as the materials are very advanced and used tough applications. Also, the recitations aren't tailored to asking questions but quizzes and group work.

His lectures barely touch on important concepts other than using online demos and he is very evasive when answering students questions in and outside of class. Many of his quizzes and exams ask very complicated questions and while he acts as though he wants "every student to get an A" I never found this to ring true.

He does a good job explaining the material to students in the class and gives a lot of online and out of class resources for students to do well. He knows his material well but does not focus on concepts heavily in class. He listens to students but is stubborn in offering fair credit. I like his lectures and do not like his exams or quizzes.

Zeke is an awesome professor! His lectures are engaging, and he does a great job with his quiz and exam writing. If you have any questions during or after class, be sure to ask them, he loves helping his students learn.

He really cares about his students and has a somewhat entertaining lecture--the most entertaining he can make it. Tests arent too difficult, but it is a difficult class so be prepared to study a lot and fail a few quizzes or a midterm. Students tend to do fairly well so dont expect a huge curve at the end. Best physics prof I've had so far.

I wish every lecturer would follow Dr. J-H's lead and post their notes/recordings of each lecture online. Learning in a lecture hall just doesn't work for me, so doing it on my own time was great as I could pause, rewind, and slow down the lesson. Props for teaching in the 21st century unlike the rest of OSU's staff. Fair tests/quizzes as well.
Great
Amazing demos and lectures.

Like some others have said don't trust the ratings for physics 1251. He is actually my favorite professor I have had at OSU, and I took this class during my 5th semester. The class is not easy, but Zeke makes it as bearable as he can. The HW is kinda rough but the lectures really help you get the basic idea. He is the best prof for this class.

It is true that dr. Halperin can make mistakes that cause confusion for the class. Its unfortunate but he always fixes the mistake and posts an updated version online. He cares about the students. He rarely went off topic even though his research seemed interesting. Class is lecture heavy. Has a study session before each test. Posts practice exams
